column1: This paper provides a near-optimal analysis of the unadjusted Langevin Monte Carlo (LMC) algorithm with respect to the W2 distance. The main statement is that the mixing time is ~ d^{1/2}/eps under standard assumptions. The authors also give a nearly matching lower bound under these assumptions. The reviewers agreed that this is an interesting contribution obtained via non-trivial techniques. The consensus recommendation is to accept the paper.
column2: This paper addresses the issue of how to estimate the convergence of the non-trivial optimizes of the optimal number of iterations of the Nash equilibrium algorithm. This is an important contribution to the field. The paper is well-written, well-motivated and well-done. The main contribution is a novel and interesting contribution. The authors have addressed the problem in a clear and clear way. The reviewers are in agreement that the paper is a solid contribution. There are some concerns about the clarity and clarity of the paper, and that the authors should address the concerns raised by the reviewers.

column1: The paper presents an approach to learn the surrogate loss for complex prediction tasks where the task loss is non-differentiable and non-decomposable. The novelty of the approach is to rely on differentiable sorting, optimizing the spearman correlation between the true loss and the surrogate. This leads to a pipeline that is simpler to integrate to existing works than approaches that try to learn a differentiable approximation to the task loss, and to better experimental results. The paper is well written and the approach clearly presented. The reviewers liked the simplicity of the approach and the promising experimental results on a variety of challenging tasks (human pose estimation and machine reading).
column2: This paper proposes a new learning method to learn the loss functions of a model by adding a loss function. The paper studies the problem of how to estimate the convergence of the training data and the performance of the model. This is a novel and interesting idea, and the proposed method is well motivated and well motivated. The proposed method can be widely applied to NLP and CLR tasks, and its benefits are significant, as shown by the experimental results.

column1: This paper studies the role of positional and relational embedding s for multi-task reinforcement learning with transformer-based policies, The paper is well-motivated, the experiment shows its effectiveness against other competitive methods. In the rebuttal period, the authors solved most of the reviews’ questions such as novelty and ablation studies. There are still some concerns about the generalizability of this approach for other tasks and more experiments are needed.
column2: This paper proposes a method to learn a transformer-based policy based on the structure of a robot. The proposed approach is well-written and well-motivated. The reviewers are generally positive about the paper, with some concerns about the novelty of the work. The authors have provided a thorough rebuttal to the reviewers' concerns. The AC agrees with the reviewers that the paper is well written and the experiments are well-done.

column1: This paper introduces a method to determine which precision to use for the weights, as well as a quantisation method using hysteresis to improve performance with low-precision weights, including 4-bits. Reviewers tend to agree that the two points presented are useful and can have a large impact on the field. Generally, reviewers pointed out that motivations, notations and experimental studies could be improved. This has been partly addressed by the authors. I recommend to accept this paper for ICLR 2022.
column2: This paper proposes a metric to estimate the performance of a variety of computators, based on the size of the training data. The paper is well-written and well-motivated. The reviewers agree that the paper is a valuable contribution to the field. The authors have addressed a number of concerns raised by the reviewers, and the reviewers are encouraged by the contributions.

column1: Overall, this paper receives positive reviews. The reviewers find the technical novelty and contributions are significant enough for acceptance at this conference. The authors' rebuttal helps address some issues. The area chair agrees with the reviewers and recommend it be accepted at this conference.
column2: This paper proposes a method to learn the distribution of the noise in a class of images. The proposed method is end-to-end trainable, and can be used to improve image classification performance. The authors propose a training method that uses a sub-network to adapt to the domain of the image. The main contribution of this paper is the use of the training method, which uses a training and training-based loss function. The paper is well-motivated, well-written, and the experimental results are thorough and thorough. The reviewers are generally positive about the paper, with some concerns about the novelty of the approach.

column1: This paper presents a way of using multigrid techniques to parallelize GRU networks across the time dimension. Reviewers are uniformly in favor of accepting the paper. The main strength is that the paper provides a new perspective on dealing with long input sequences by parallelizing RNNs across time. The main weaknesses are around the experiments: only CPU experiments are run, and sequences are not very long (max 128 length). All-in-all, though, it provides an interesting perspective that should be valuable to the community.
column2: This paper proposes a new method to improve the performance of neural networks with large number of training data. The proposed method is based on a multi-sparsicization method for neural networks that can be used in a variety of domains. The paper is well written and clear, and the experimental results on the dataset are impressive. The reviewers agreed that the paper is an interesting contribution to the field. The main concerns raised by the reviewers were about novelty and novelty of the method, but the authors addressed these concerns in the rebuttal.

column1: This paper introduces a technique to generate L0 adversarial examples in a black-box manner. The reviews are largely positive, with the reviewers especially commenting on the paper being well written and clearly explaining the method. The main drawbacks raised by the reviewers is that the method is not clearly compared to some prior work, but in the rebuttal the authors provide many of these numbers. On the whole this is a useful and interesting attack that would be worth accepting.
column2: This paper proposes a new adversarial adversarial attack for adversarial learning. The proposed methods are well-motivated and novel. The paper is well-written and the experimental results are thorough and thorough. The main concern is that the authors have not provided a thorough analysis of existing work on adversarial training.

Specifically, the fact that this reviewer directly asks e. g. for comparisons to Levine and Feiz 2019, when the paper (before its revisions) contains an entire section devoted to exactly this comparison, strikes me as not sufficient for a thorough review. column2: This paper proposes a new method for improving the robustness of deep learning neural networks. The paper is well-written and well-motivated, and the reviewers agree that the paper is interesting and novel. The reviewers found some concerns about the novelty of the method, and that the method is not very generalized. The authors did a good job in addressing reviewers' concerns, and all reviewers agreed that this is a nice paper to accept. The main concerns raised by the reviewers have been addressed by the authors, and I recommend the authors to address them in the rebuttal.

column1: The paper presents interesting new results for pruning random convolutional networks to approximate a target function. It follows a recent line of work in the topic of pruning by learning. The results are novel, and the techniques interesting. There are some technical issues that are easy to fix within the camera ready timeline (see comments of reviewers below). I would also suggest refining the title of the paper: the lottery ticket hypothesis has an algorithmic component too, which clearly is not covered by existence results.
column2: This paper proposes a method to learn neural networks by training them with a training-based algorithm. The proposed method is based on the Liestein-Sinkstein-Torsion (LSTO) problem. The reviewers agreed that the paper is well-written and the results are interesting. There were some concerns about the novelty of the method, and the simplicity of the results. The authors did a good job in addressing reviewers' concerns.

column1: The paper introduces a pipeline to discover PDEs from scarce and noisy data. Reviewers engaged in a very thoughtful discussion with the authors. I read the extensive rebuttal, and I believe the authors have addressed the major concerns claimed by the reviewers. I ask the authors to make sure to include all the changes and additional experiments in the camera-ready version.
column2: This paper proposes a new method to learn how to train a neural network with a large batch of data. The paper is well-written, well-motivated and well-done, with a number of clarifications and clarifications. The authors did a good job in the rebuttal phase, and addressed some of the concerns raised by the reviewers. There were some minor concerns about the clarity of the paper, and that the writing is not clear.

column1: The authors introduce a method that improves goal-conditioned supervised learning (GCSL) by iteratively re-weighting the experience by a variable that correlates with the number of steps till the desired goal. The reviewers mention that the authors focus on an important problem, their method is simple and the empirical results are significant. However, they do point several flaws of the paper, the main ones being questionable theoretical claims and the clarity of the presentation. After an extensive discussion, most reviewers agree that the paper should be accepted but I do encourage the authors to take into account the comments by the reviewers for the final version of the paper and make the theory more clear.
column2: This paper proposes a method for learning policy-based reinforcement learning based on data. The reviewers agreed that the paper is well-written and the empirical results are strong. There were some concerns about the novelty of the method, and the clarity of the paper. The authors did a good job in addressing the concerns raised by the reviewers. I recommend acceptance of this paper.

column1: This paper presents a neural version of individual-refinement (IR) architecture for improving the expressiveness of GNN in terms of isomorphism tests. As IR is the dominant approach of practical graph isomorphism tests, adapting IR to GNN is a novel and important idea. As IR suffers from the exponential number of branches, the paper adapts particle filtering algorithms to sample K paths to approximate the full version of the IR algorithm. Simulation and real-world datasets are used to demonstrate the improvement over base GNN. Strengths: + The paper is well written and easy to follow. + The originality of the paper is high since it is both technically rich. Adapting
column2: This paper proposes a new method to learn graph representations. The model is shown to be very effective in graph isomorphism testing and in the detection of graph properties. The authors also show that the model outperforms the baselines on three real-world datasets. The paper is well written and the empirical results are strong. The main weakness is the complexity of the model, and it is not clear how practical and practical the approach can be.

column1: This paper proposes an identifiable nonlinear ICA model based on volume-preserving transformations. The overall approach is very similar to the GIN method published @ ICLR 2020. There is a weak consensus among the reviewers that this paper has some merit, although none pushed for acceptance. After reviewing the paper myself, I agree that the contributions here appear to be incremental, but the results do push this growing field of identifiable latent variable models forward.
column2: This paper proposes a new framework for the generative generative generation of graph convolutional data, based on the GIN model. The authors provide theoretical support for the use of the pre-existing Gin model for ICA, and demonstrate that the proposed method outperforms the existing method. The paper is well-written, and the experimental results show that the method performs outperforming the state-of-the-art nonlinear ICA method (iVAE). The authors also provide two theorems for nonlinear and linear invariance, which show that it is a simple problem to estimate the number of latent variables in a graph.

column1: The paper presents a method for cooperative ad-hoc collaboration by learning latent representations of the teammates. The method is evaluated in three domains. All the reviewers agree that the method is novel and adds an interesting contribution to the important and difficult problem of the ad-hoc collaboration, making fewer assumptions about the team and the teammates. The next version of the paper should comment: - On the societal impact of the centralized training. - Wang et al, CoRL 2020, https://arxiv. org/abs/2003.06906, which addresses the cooperative tasks in the ad-hoc teams without privileged knowledge and assumptions about the teammates.
column2: This paper studies the problem of how to learn an agent-based RL model using a latent variable model. The reviewers agreed that the paper is well-written and well-motivated. The main concerns raised by the reviewers were the novelty and novelty of the proposed approach, and the novelty of this work. The authors did a good job in the rebuttal and addressed most of the concerns raised during the discussion. The AC agrees with the reviewers that the proposed method is interesting and novel, and is well motivated. There were some concerns about the novelty, but the authors addressed these in the revised version.

The Authors first draw attention to the fact that using recalculated moments boosts performance and reduces forgetting, which serves as an argument that at least partially BN contributes to catastrophic forgetting in continual learning. Given that BN remains quite important in certain application areas such as vision, it is a strong motivation for the paper. The experiments are thorough and clearly show that CN is a practically relevant alternative to BN in continual learning. The reviewers agreed that the paper is well-motivated and well-written, and the empirical evaluation is impressive. The authors did a good job in addressing reviewers' concerns about the novelty of the proposed method. The main concerns raised by the reviewers were that the authors did not address some of the reviewers' comments in the rebuttal. The AC agrees with the reviewers and recommends acceptance.

column1: The manuscript develops a new kind of graph neural network (a Graph Mechanics Network; GMN) that is particularly well suited to representing and making predictions about physical mechanics systems (and data with similar structure). It does so by developing a way to build geometric constraints implicitly and naturally into the forward kinematics of the network, while still allowing for effective learning from data. The manuscript proves some essential properties of the new architecture and runs experiments both with simulated particles, hinges, sticks (and their combination), as well as with motion capture data. Reviewers were generally impressed by the writing and clarity of the work, as well as the main results. In addition, in those cases where reviewers thought that
column2: This paper proposes a new method for learning a neural network based on an object-centric model. The reviewers agreed that the paper is well-motivated, well-written and well-done. The authors did a good job of addressing the concerns raised by the reviewers and provided a thorough analysis of the proposed approach. There is a lack of novelty and scope in the work, and it is not clear to me how the authors will tackle these concerns in the rebuttal phase. The paper is a solid contribution to the field of deep learning, and the reviewers are in agreement with the importance of this work.

The authors point out the interesting duality between continual learning and knowledge learning where: in knowledge learning one must avoid forgetting time-invariant knowledge (avoid forgetting in CL), be able to acquire new knowledge (learn new tasks in CL), and replace outdated knowledge (a form of forgetting and re-learning or adaptation). In their paper, the authors develop an initial benchmark for the task along with a set of baselines and provide empirical studies. The initial reviews were quite mixed. column2: This paper proposes a new benchmark and metric to measure the ability of the ML framework to improve performance on multiple tasks. The reviewers agree that the paper is well-motivated, well-written and well-done. There were some concerns about the novelty of the paper, and that the experimental results are not very strong. The authors did not show experiments and analysis in a setting where the new task is not very simple.

The reviewers find the problem relevant and appreciate the proposed solution. They find the paper well-written and find the empirical results on Alzheimer brain MRIs relevant for the neuroscience community. The overall objective function includes several hyper-parameters. As pointed out as the main weak point by multiple reviewers this may hint at overengineering/overfitting to a data set. All reviewers appreciate the suggested technical approach and the thorough evaluations that demonstrate clear improvements. While the technical novelty of the paper is not entirely compelling, all reviewers recommend acceptance of the paper.

column2: This paper proposes a method to learn a graph with a set of permutation functions. The paper is well-written and the reviewers agreed that the paper is interesting and well-motivated. The reviewers found the paper to be interesting and the paper was well written. The main concerns raised by the reviewers were the novelty of the model and the simplicity of the approach. The authors did a good job in addressing reviewers' concerns and addressed most of them in the rebuttal.

column1: This paper presents a new method to decrease the supervision cost for learning spurious attributes using worst-group loss minimization. Their method uses samples both with and without spurious attribute annotations to train a model to predict the spurious attribute, then use the pseudo-attribute predicted by the trained model as supervision on the spurious attribute to train a new robust model having minimal worst-group loss. The experiments show promising results in this domain for reducing annotation cost. The reviewers vote to accept the paper, and some of them increased their scores during the discussions since the authors have addressed their concerns.
column2: This paper studies the problem of how to improve the performance of adversarial learning methods. The authors propose a method that uses pseudo-labeling to improve performance of the training data. The main idea is to learn the class of the class from the class data, and the class distribution from the classification data. They show that the method performs better than previous methods that use a sub-class-based loss function. The paper is well-written, well-motivated, and well-done. The reviewers agree that the approach is interesting, well motivated, and novel. There are some concerns about the novelty of the method, and that the experiments are limited.

It holds merit as an interesting novel application of CVAEs to the ML for combinatorial optimization literature, as well as for the nice empirical results which show a very nice improvement. Under fairly standard conditionally-independence assumptions, the paper uses known Bayesian filtering/smoothing tricks to derive a recursive estimation algorithm and a parameter-estimation method based on a simple maximum likelihood objective. Both theoretical and empirical justifications are presented to elaborate that neural collapse generalizes to new samples from the training classes, and to new classes as well. The problem that this paper delves into is important. The paper is well-motivated, and well structured with a good flow. Both theoretical and empirical analyses of the paper are solid. The authors did a good job in addressing the concerns raised by the reviewers. Overall, the reviewers agreed that the paper was a solid contribution to the field.

column1: One way of avoiding catastrophic forgetting in continual learning is through keeping a memory buffer for experience replay. This paper addresses the problem of online selection of representative samples for populating such memory buffer for experience replay. The paper proposes novel information-theoretic criteria that selects samples that captures surprise (samples that are most informative) and learnability (to avoid outliers). They utilize a Bayesian formulation to quantify informativeness. They provide two algorithms: a greedy approach, and an approach that takes timing (when to) update memory into account based on reservoir sampling to mitigate possible issues with class imbalance. The authors are encouraged to address these concerns in the final version of the paper.

column1: The paper introduces As-ViT, an interesting framework for searching and scaling ViTs without training. Overall, the paper received positive reviews. On the other hand, R1 rated the paper as marginally below the threshold, raising concerns about search on small datasets and issues regarding the comparison in terms of FLOPS/accuracy with other methods. The authors adequately addressed these concerns in the rebuttal, and helped clarify other questions by R2 and R3. R1 did not participate in the discussion after the author response nor updated his/her review. The AC agrees with R2 and R3 that the paper passes the acceptance bar of ICLR, as the unified approach for efficient search
column2: This paper studies the problem of how to improve the performance of vision transformers. The authors propose a new neural architecture search based on a multi-scale vision transformer, as well as a training-free approach. The proposed approach is evaluated on image classification, classification and detection tasks. The reviewers are generally positive about the paper, with some concerns about the novelty of the approach, and the effectiveness of the proposed approach. Overall, the reviewers agree that the paper is an interesting contribution to the community.

column1: This paper introduces a differentiable yarn-level model of fabrics. The model is more detailed and physically realistic than proposed in earlier work, which may allow for applications to manufacturing guidance and textile design. The paper is generally well-written and contains detailed problem formulation and derivations. Experiments show it is possible to successfully learn a control policy and material parameters using the differentiable model.
column2: This paper studies the problem of how to train a complex molecular robot with a simple molecular structure. The authors provide a novel way to learn the dynamics of a molecular robot. The reviewers agree that the paper is well-motivated, well-written and the experimental results are impressive. The main concern is that the reviewers are not able to understand the authors' claim that the proposed method is more efficient than the previous work.

column1: The paper investigates the use of flow models for out-of-distribution detection. The paper proposes to use a combination of random projections in the latent space of flow models and one-sample / two-sample statistical tests for detecting OOD inputs. The authors present results on image benchmarks as well as non-image benchmarks. The reviewers found the approach well-motivated and appreciated the ablations. The authors did a good job of addressing reviewer concerns during the rebuttal. During the discussion phase, the consensus decision leaned towards acceptance. I recommend accept and encourage the reviewers to address any remaining concerns in the final version. It might be worth discussing this paper in the related work: Density
column2: This paper studies the problem of how to learn how to tackle OOD in the context of high-dimensional data. The proposed approach is interesting, simple, and well-motivated. The paper is well-written and the idea of the paper is clear. The method is novel, to the best of all the reviewers' knowledge. The reviewers were generally positive about the novelty of the proposed approach. The authors did a good job of comparing the proposed method to other baselines. The main concerns raised by the reviewers were that the method is simple to use and the results are easy to interpret.

column1: This work identifies an interesting bias that can occur when applying occlusion based interpretability methods to debug image classifiers. For context, the motivation behind many of these methods is that by occluding various parts of the image, one can ask counterfactuals such as "what would the model have predicted if this object were not present in the image"? However, the authors note that when occluding pixels, classifiers are still functions of the occlusions themselves, so this process may introduce a bias as a result. This is most clearly demonstrated in Figure 2 where a convolutional architecture classifies various occluded images as "jigsaw" or "crossword puzzle
column2: This paper studies the problem of how to handle the bias between the classifier and the input data. The authors propose a method that uses a VIT architecture to use a small number of sub-groups of a classifier, which is more robust to noise. The paper is well-written and the reviewers found the paper to be interesting. The reviewers were not convinced about the effectiveness of the proposed method, but all the reviewers agree that the paper is interesting and the authors have addressed the concerns raised by the reviewers.

column1: Reviewers all found the work well-motivated in addressing uncertainty, a topic that has not seen much focus in meta-learning and few-shot learning. They describe the challenges well: small sample sizes and OOD shift. They then propose a solution they find works well empirically to overcome these challenges based on a set encoder and an energy function respectively. The proposal is largely one of engineering components that have been found to work well in the literature. I'm sympathetic to this style of research (particularly in today's neural network research), although the reviewers raise a primary concern about whether the choices leading to the proposal are justified. In particular, two Reviewers argue that there are no
column2: This paper proposes a new method to learn the class-specific variance of a few-shot class of images. The paper is well written and well-motivated, and the reviewers found the paper well-written and clear and clear to follow. The reviewers had some concerns about the novelty of the proposed method and the use of an additional encoder to predict the task-specific covariance. The authors did a good job in addressing the concerns raised by the reviewers.

column1: This work proposes a new framework that can learn the object-centric representation for video. The authors did a good job during rebuttal and turned one slightly negative reviewer into positive ones. The final scores are 6,6,8,8. AC agrees that this work is very interesting and deserves to be published on ICLR. The reviewers did raise some valuable concerns that should be addressed in the final camera-ready version of the paper. The authors are also encouraged to make other necessary changes.
column2: This paper proposes a method to learn object representations from video. The paper is well written, and the technical details are easy to follow. The main issue with the method is the inability to be generalized to real-world data. The authors are encouraged to address these concerns in the final version of the paper.

column1: The results reported in this paper and the model checkpoints released are of interest and broad utility to the community in the opinion of the NLP. While one reviewer was somewhat negative, most reviewers were in favor of acceptance of this paper, which expands the results from [1] to downstream tasks. The AC therefore recommends acceptance.
column2: This paper proposes a new method to improve the performance of deep neural language models. The reviewers agreed that the paper is well-written, well-motivated and the experiments are thorough. There were some concerns about the novelty of the work and the lack of experiments on other models. Overall, the reviewers found the paper to be above the acceptance threshold for acceptance.

column1: The paper describes an approach for automatically generating CAD sketches, including both the primitives that describe the drawing, as well as the constraints that describe relationships between the primitives that need to be maintained even if the primitives are changed. This is an important problem that is starting to receive a lot of attention from the literature. Overall, the paper is very well executed and the results are quite compelling. There were some concerns about the relationship with the work by Willis et al. and other papers that were published around the time when this paper was submitted. There is still some novelty in this paper relative to those works as argued in appendix H, but it would have been really good to have a more
column2: This paper proposes a method for learning to generate graph representations of video images. The paper is well-written, and the shown results show good performance on the dataset that is used for training. The main concern about this paper is about the novelty of the proposed method, but the reviewers agree that it is a nice contribution to the field. The reviewers are encouraged to clarify the technical contributions of the method in the final version of the paper.

column1: This paper proposes a new time-varying convolutional architecture (ST-GNN) for dynamic graphs. The reviewers were positive about the presentation and detailed theory, especially on the stability analysis. The shared criticism was on experimental validation synthetic datasets that the reviewers did not find appealing. The AC believes that while the lacking validation concerns are legit, there is a lack of sophisticated dynamic graph benchmarks in the community yet, so the authors did their best effort to test their method. We thus recommend to accept the paper.
column2: This paper proposes a new architecture based on their new architecture and using the finite impulse response (FIR) filter. The reviewers agreed that the paper is well-written and well-motivated, and the reviewers found the theoretical contributions strong. The authors did a good job in the rebuttal, though the reviewers had some concerns about experiments on real-world datasets. The main concerns raised by the reviewers were that the experimental evaluation of the proposed method is not very comprehensive, and that the experiments are not very accessible to the ICLR community.

column1: The submission develops a rotationally equivariant scattering transform on the sphere. Many developments in deep learning make use of spherical representations, and the development of a rotationally equivariant scattering transform is an important if not unexpected development. The reviews are split with half of the reviewers believing it to be slightly above the threshold for acceptance, and half believe it to be slightly below the threshold for acceptance. In the papers favor, it solves an important case of the scattering transform framework, which has been demonstrated to be important in diverse machine learning applications such as learning with small data sets, differentially private learning, and network initialization. As such, continued fundamental development in this area is valuable, especially in
column2: This paper proposes a new method to train deep neural networks with high-resolution convolutional neural networks. The proposed method is based on the convexity of the permutation function of a flow-based neural network. The paper is well-written, well-motivated and the experimental results are well-done. The reviewers agree that the paper is a solid contribution to the field. The authors are encouraged to address the concerns raised by the reviewers in the rebuttal phase.

column1: This paper provides some empirical investigation of the choice of the prior distribution for the weights in Bayesian neural networks. It shows empirically that, when trained via SGD, weights in feedforward neural networks exhibit heavy-tails, while weights in convolutional neural networks are spatially correlated. From this observation they show that the use of such priors leads to some improved performances compared to the iid Gaussian prior in some experimental settings. Reviewers have conflicting views on this paper, that have not been reconcilied after the author's response and the discussion. On the plus side, the paper is very well written, the experimental part is carefully conducted, and provides some insights on the choice
column2: This paper proposes a new method to learn how to estimate the probability of an agent using a Gaussian distribution, and shows that it outperforms the previous methods. The paper is well-written, well-motivated, and the authors provide a thorough analysis of the empirical results. The reviewers agree that the paper is an interesting contribution to the field, and I recommend acceptance. The authors did a good job in the rebuttal, and all reviewers agreed that this paper is a solid contribution.

column1: The main detractor of this paper feels that the paper makes a relatively small technical and empirical contribution given existing results on HER (Andrychowicz et al., NeurIPS 2017). However, several other reviewers, who had more engagement in the discussion, were strong supporters. Having looked at the paper myself I thought the selection of experimental problems undermined the results. Experiments are most compelling when many unaffiliated groups compete on the same benchmarks. But the basic idea of integrating HER with AlphaZero, and a reasonable attempt at this, seems to be interesting enough to warrant a poster.
column2: This paper proposes to use the idea of self-supervised reinforcement learning to solve the problem of goal-driven reinforcement learning. The reviewers agreed that the paper is well-written and well-motivated. The main concerns raised by the reviewers have been adequately addressed by the authors. The authors did a good job in addressing the concerns raised in the paper, and addressed the concerns in the rebuttal. There was a concern about the novelty of the work, and the authors addressed this by adding additional experiments.

column1: Kernel methods are among the most flexible and powerful approaches of our times. Random features (RF) provide a recent mechanism to also make them scalable due to the associated finite (and often small)-dimensional approximate feature map (in the paper referred to as linearization). The focus of the submission is the linearization of the softmax kernel (defined in (1)) while making sure that the obtained RF approximation is accurate simultaneously for the small and the large kernel values. The authors present a hybrid random feature (HRF, defined in (8)) construction parameterized by base estimators and weights, and show that specific choice of these parameters is capable of implementing the goal. Some of the HR
column2: This paper proposes a new method to learn how to learn to learn the state of the art of graph convolutional neural networks. The paper is well-written, well-motivated and well-done. The authors have addressed a number of concerns about the novelty of the approach. The reviewers are in agreement that the paper is interesting, and that the results are interesting. The main concern is that it is not clear about the importance of this work, and the authors should address this.

column1: This paper presents a comparison and analysis of continual learning methods for pretrained language models. The authors categorise continual learning methods into three categories, those that use cross task regularisation, those that employ some form of experience replay of previous training examples, and those that dynamically alter the network architecture for each task. Evaluation results from representative examples of these three paradigms are then presented and analysed. In general methods that incorporate experience reply appear to perform the best, while analysis of the predictive power of individual layers of the pretrained models suggests that some network layers are more robust to catastrophic forgetting than others, and that this also varies across architectures (BERT, ALBERT, etc.). In general
column2: This paper presents an interesting and well-motivated study on the problem of fine-tuning self-supervised learning. The reviewers agree that the paper is well-written and the experimental results are interesting and clear. The authors have provided a thorough analysis of the reviewers' feedback on the paper, and the authors also provided an interesting analysis on the authors' response to reviewers' concerns about the paper. Overall, the reviewers found the paper to be a solid contribution to the community of the ICLR literature.

column1: The paper tackles the important problem of spurious feature detection in deep neural networks. Specifically, it proposes a framework to identify core and spurious features by investigating the activation maps with human supervision. Then, it produces an annotated version of the ImageNet dataset with core and spurious features, called Salient ImageNet, which is then used to empirically assess the robustness of the method against spurious training signals in comparison with current SOTA models. As pointed out by the reviewers, this work is not about causality and the definitions of causal and spurious features were originally vague and inaccurate. During the revision and discussion, the authors changed the terms "causal" features/accuracy to "core"
column2: This paper studies how to learn how to predict how a model is dependent on dependency on noise in the training set. The authors propose a method to learn that the model is not very robust. The paper is well-written, well-motivated, and the approach is interesting and novel. The reviewers agree that the paper addresses the main concerns raised by the reviewers. There are some concerns about the novelty of the approach and the simplicity of the proposed approach.

column1: The authors proposed an algorithm for sampling DAGs that is suited for continuous optimization. The sampling algorithm has two main steps: In the first step, a causal order over the variables is selected. In the second step, edges are sampled based on the selected order. Moreover, based on this algorithm, they proposed a method in order to learn the causal structure from the observational data. The causal structure learning algorithm is guaranteed to output a DAG at any time and it is not required any pre- or post-processing unlike previous work. There were concerns by two reviewers on the slight lack of novelty ("the proposed method of this paper is only a combination of well-developed techniques") but I
column2: This paper proposes a new method for the learning of DAG structure learning using gradient-based methods. The proposed method is simple and novel, and the experimental evaluation is thorough. The reviewers agree that the paper is well-written, well-motivated, and well-done. The main concern is that the proposed method of this paper is only a combination of well-funded techniques. The authors are encouraged to address these concerns in the rebuttal.

column1: The paper examines the advantage of using models in RL. The authors' rebuttals convinced us of the value of the paper.
column2: This paper studies the problem of how to estimate the speed of the policy-based policy based on the state of the environment. The paper is well-written, well-motivated, and the proposed method is simple and simple to understand. The reviewers were generally positive about the paper, with some concerns about the novelty and novelty of the proposed approach. The authors did a good job in the rebuttal, with the main concerns raised by the reviewers that the paper was not clear in the presentation of the results.

column1: The reviewers agree that addressing long-horizon tasks with off-line learning and fine tuning afterwards from demonstrations is an interesting and relevant topic. The technical ideas about learning a relevance metric to select relevant off-line data, and to learn an inverse skill dynamics models. The experimental results are convincing, even if success rates are sometimes lower than expected. All reviewers recommend acceptance of the paper.
column2: This paper proposes a method to learn a new task using an adversarial policy-based approach. The proposed method is intuitive and shows potential for a powerful agent that can adapt to a variety of environments. The reviewers agree that the paper is well-motivated, well-written and the experimental results are impressive. The authors are encouraged to make the paper more detailed and the authors have addressed the concerns raised by the reviewers.

column1: The authors introduce a novel probabilistic hierarchical clustering method for graphs. In particular they design an end-to-end gradient-based learning to optimize the Dasgupta cost and Tree Sampling Divergence cost at the same time. Overall the paper presents solid results both from a theoretical and experimental perspective so I think it is a good fit for the conference and I suggest accepting it.
column2: This paper proposes a novel and interesting approach to the problem of sampling graph embeddings in the context of a graph structure. The paper is well-written and well-motivated, the experiments are thorough and the experimental results are impressive. The reviewers agree that the approach is novel and is interesting, and the reviewers are satisfied with the empirical results. There are some concerns about the novelty of the approach and the simplicity of the experiments. The authors are encouraged to address these concerns in the rebuttal.

column1: This paper introduces a benchmark for experimental design algorithms for an important cellular biological question, causal discovery of effective genetic knock-out interventions. It uses existing datasets. The paper was discussed by the reviewers after the authors correctly pointed out that methodological machine learning novelty is not a necessary condition for accepting papers. Two reviewers increased their scores and all are slightly positive. The benchmark was seen as valuable, and one reviewer even commented they might use it in their own research. However, the paper is still on the borderline as this benchmark is only a first step. It has not been shown yet that machine learning insights can be produced with it, as the authors have not actually used it for benchmarking yet. In
column2: This paper proposes a new method for learning to learn to learn from data. The reviewers agreed that the paper is well-written, well-motivated, and well-done. The authors have addressed the problem of causal inference in robotic AI, and provided a thorough analysis of the empirical results. The paper is very interesting, and the reviewers found that the reviewers had some concerns about the novelty and significance of the work. The main concerns raised by the reviewers were that the authors did not provide a thorough assessment of the experimental evaluation of the proposed methods, and that the experiments were limited to a small batch of data.

column1: Although reviews were initially a little polarized, they trend toward accepting the paper after rebuttal and discussion. The most negative review raised issues of datasets, baselines, and experiments, and various details that they find confusing. These concerns were not shared by the other reviewers for the most part. Following a detailed rebuttal the most negative reviewer ended up siding with the more positive reviewers.
column2: This paper studies the problem of learning graph representation learning with class-imbalance problem. The paper proposes a method for learning graph representations that uses the class of the sub-class of the input data. The proposed method is based on a graph neural network, and shows good empirical results. The reviewers agree that the paper is well-motivated and well-written, and the proposed algorithm is simple and novel. The main concerns raised by the reviewers are about the novelty of the method, the simplicity of the approach and the lack of clarity on the approach. The authors are encouraged to address these concerns in the final version of the paper.

column1: In this paper, a new method is proposed to discover diverse policies solving a given task. The key ideas are to (1) learn one policy at a time, with each new policy trying to be different enough from the previous ones, and (2) switch between two rewards on a per-trajectory basis: the "normal" reward on trajectories that are unlikely enough under previoiusly discovered policies, and a "diversity-inducing" reward on trajectories that are too likely (so as to push the policy being learned away from the previous ones). The main benefit of this switching mechanism is to ensure that the new policy will be optimal, because the reward signal isn
column2: This paper proposes a method for improving the performance of deep reinforcement learning. The reviewers agreed that the paper is well-written and well-motivated, and the experimental evaluation is impressive. The main concerns raised by the reviewers have been addressed by the authors in the rebuttal. The authors are encouraged to address these concerns in the revised version of the paper. The AC agrees with the reviewers that the authors have addressed the concerns raised in the paper in the revision.

column1: The paper presents a neural architecture based on neural memory modules to model the spatiotemporal traffic data. The reviewers think this is an important application of deep learning and thus fits the topic of ICLR. The writing and the novelty of the proposed method need improvement.
column2: This paper proposes a new method for learning data-based predictions of time series. The paper is well written and well-written, well-motivated, and the experimental results are impressive. The main concern is that the paper is not well written, and that the setting of the problem is not clear. The authors are not clear on the complexity of the model and the design of the network. The approach is novel, novel, and well motivated. The reviewers agree that this paper is an interesting and novel contribution to the field.

column1: The paper provides the theoretical justification for the "label trick" (using labels in graph-based semisupervised learning tasks). The authors performed a thorough evaluation of their analysis, which constitutes an experimental contribution. The authors provided a rebuttal that the AC finds to have reasonably addressed the reviewers' concerns. We recommend acceptance.
column2: This paper proposes a new framework for GNNs where the non-deterministic label trick is used in the training of the model. The reviewers agree that the paper is well-written, well-motivated, and the proposed use cases are interesting and novel. The main concern is that the authors are not clear on the importance of the label trick in general, and that the experiments on the training and use of the pre-trained model are not thorough and thorough. The authors also have some concerns about the experimental evaluation of the proposed methods. The AC agrees with the reviewers that this paper is a solid contribution to the field.

column1: This paper adapts a method called "real-time recurrent learning" for training recurrent neural networks. The idea is to project the true gradient onto a subspace of desired dimensionality along a candidate direction. There are a variety of possible candidates: random directions, backpropagation through time, meta-learning approaches, etc. The main strength of the paper is that it is a very simple idea that seems to have practical utility. While often presented in different contexts, it should be clearly noted by the authors that the general idea of using low dimensional directional derivatives for computational efficiency is fairly common in optimization. Reviewers mention sketch and project methods. This has also been looked, for example,
column2: This paper proposes a new approach to gradient-based optimization for RL architectures. The paper is well-written, well-motivated, and is well motivated. The reviewers agree that the paper is interesting and novel. The main concerns raised by the reviewers have been addressed by the authors in the rebuttal.

column1: The reviewers thought this paper tackles an interesting question around whether MaxEnt RL already provides an important form of robustness. Such work helps us better understand the intersection between generalization, regularization and robustness. The reviewers had a number of comments, questions and clarifications and were generally satisfied with the detailed responses provided by the authors. There was some concern over the strength of the experiments and the authors also ran additional experiments. These addressed one reviewer’s concerns, though the other still thought the existing experiments were a bit too simple.
column2: This paper studies the problem of how to learn a policy that optimizes a policy with a non-trivial policy function. The reviewers agree that the paper is well-written and well-motivated, and the results are well-done. The authors are not clear about the significance of the results and the novelty of the proposed approach, but the reviewers are in agreement that it is interesting and novel. There are some concerns about the clarity of the paper and the ability of the authors to address these concerns in the rebuttal phase.

column1: This paper presents a probabilistic framework that explains why models trained adversarially are robust generators. It received fairly high initial scores. The reviewers thought the work was novel and interesting. They liked that the analysis provided a way to derive a novel training method and sampling algorithms. Reviewers confirmed their support of acceptance and I think this paper is clearly above the bar. Respectfully, I’d prefer that the authors don’t ask the reviewers to “raise your score”. It is up to the reviewers to make that decision.
column2: This paper presents a novel perspective to adversarial training. The paper proposes a novel method for sampling from an unsupervised adversarially trained model. The authors show that adversarial sampling methods derived from the paper outperform (and outperform) other adversarial learning methods. Overall, the paper is well-written, well-motivated, and well-done. The reviewers agree that the authors have addressed a number of concerns.

column1: This work studies the question of increasing the expressive power of GNNs by adding positional encodings while preserving equivariance and stability to graph perturbations. Reviewers were generally positive about this work, highlighting its judicious problem setup, identifying the right notion of stability and how it should drive the design of positional encodings. Despite some concerns about the discrepancy between the theoretical results and the empirical evaluation, the consensus was ultimately that this work is an interesting contribution, and therefore the AC recommends acceptance.
column2: This paper proposes a method to learn graph embeddings in graph neural networks. The proposed approach is well motivated and well-motivated, and the writing is well-written. The paper is well written and the results are demonstrated on multiple datasets. The reviewers agree that the paper is interesting and novel. The main concerns raised by the reviewers have been addressed in the rebuttal phase.

column1: The paper presents a backdoor attack approach against pre-trained models that may affect different downstream languages tasks with the same trigger. The paper shows that the downstream models can inherit security holes from upstream pre-trained models. The paper is on the borderline and disagreement remains after discussion and author responses. In general, the new setting introduced in the paper is interesting and well-motivated. However, the options split in how realistic the setting is (e. g., use of uncommon trigger), the evaluation of stealthiness, and the novelty of the idea. After checking the paper, I believe the ideas and insights are justifiable for an ICLR paper and they differ significantly enough from the prior work
column2: This paper presents a novel approach to the problem of introducing task-agnostic backdoor attacks to pretrained NLP models. The paper is well-written and the experiments are extensive and sound, and the proposed method is simple and effective. The reviewers agree that the paper is a solid contribution, and I recommend acceptance. The main concern is that the reviewers are not fully convinced about the empirical evaluation and how the proposed approach can be used in practice.

column1: The authors theoretically analyze the approximation of Korobov functions by neural networks, obtaining upper and nearly matching lower bounds, for shallow and deep networks, with different activation functions. The bounds are stronger than what can be proved for the more commonly studied Sobolev functions. But Korobov functions are a natural and fairly wide class of functions. This work makes a substantial step forward in clarifying what kind of functions are especially amenable to representation by neural networks. The reviewers also appreciated the clarity of the writing.
column2: The paper is well written and the theoretical results are well-motivated, and the results are clear and sound. The paper is very well-written and the reviewers agree that the paper is a solid contribution to the community of ICLR. The reviewers are generally positive about the paper, with some concerns about the novelty and novelty of the results. The main concerns are that the work is not clear, and that the reviewers are not able to understand the theoretical analysis of the paper.

column1: We appreciate the authors for addressing the comments raised by the reviewers during the discussion period, which includes providing more experimental results to address the concerns. We believe the publication of this paper can contribute to the important topic of data augmentation. The authors are highly recommended to consider all the comments and suggestions made by the reviewers when further revising their paper for publication.
column2: This paper proposes a method to learn an augmentation policy using an adversarial objective. The proposed method is a simple, intuitive, simple to apply and effective on several datasets. The authors also show good experimental results on several tasks. The paper is well-written and well-motivated with extensive experiments. The main concern is that the authors did not consider the importance of the class-imbalanced dataset. The reviewers are encouraged to incorporate the authors' responses in the final version.

column1: The authors present a new memory-augmented neural network that is related to the Kanerva machine of Wu et. al. The reviewers considered the ideas in the paper novel and interesting, but were concerned about presentation issues and literature review. The authors have improved both... however- authors: please even under limited space constraints, make more room for related work! Clarifying your contribution in the context of the literature is critical for reader understanding, and neglecting this almost had your paper rejected out of hand. I am voting to accept
column2: This paper proposes an efficient algorithm for the training of RL agents. The paper is well-written and empirically motivated, and the experimental evaluation is thorough. The reviewers found that the paper is not clear and the presentation of the paper was not clear. The authors did a good job in the rebuttal phase, but the paper should be improved in the final version. Overall, the reviewers found the paper well written and the empirical evaluation well motivated.

column1: Four knowledgeable referees recommend Accept. I also think the paper provides a unique contribution to the field of deep survival models and I, therefore, recommend Accept
column2: This paper proposes a new latent variable model for clustering distribution data. The proposed method is compared against a large range of previous methods. The reviewers agreed that the paper is well-written and well-motivated. The main concern raised by the reviewers was about the novelty of the proposed method, and the lack of clarity in the presentation of the results.

column1: The reviewers are all weakly positive. The author response clarified important aspects of the paper. The new human evaluation was critical. However, the human evaluation result presentation is flawed: presenting Likert scores as means does not reflect them well. The authors should use something similar to a Gantt chart to fully reflect the distribution across Likert categories. Another detail in the human evaluation that are troubling: it does not reflect interaction with the system, but judgements through observation. Therefore, the human evaluation does not reflect the ability of the learned dialogue system to interact with users. Overall, the paper makes a nice, original contribution, but despite author improvement there are evaluation flaws (even if
column2: This paper studies the problem of learning a policy-based RL model based on a pre-trained language model and offline RL. The proposed method performs better than existing methods on a variety of environments. The reviewers agree that the proposed method is novel and the experimental results are impressive. There are some concerns about the novelty of the method, and the paper is not clear about the experiments. The authors are encouraged to address these concerns in the final version of the paper. The paper is well-written and well-motivated.

column1: This paper introduces a soft gradient-based subword tokenization module (GBST) that learns latent subword representations from characters. GBST enumerates candidate subword blocks and learns to score them in a position-wise fashion using a block scoring network. The resulting model was tested on GLUE, and several cross-lingual tasks. The performance is competitive with ByteT5 and often similar to subword models while being more efficient in FLOPs and RAM. Reviewers are mixed on this. The negative reviewer points to how this not being a real tokenizer and does not produce a tokenization, that experiments that use the base model do not address bigger scales, and that there
column2: This paper studies the problem of how to learn the latent representations of a set of unsupervised sub-models. The reviewers are in agreement that the proposed method is interesting, well-motivated, and novel. The authors are encouraged to incorporate the reviewers' feedback in the final version of the paper. The main concerns raised by the reviewers are that the paper is not clear and the technical details are not clear.

column1: This paper proposes an extension to learning a representation: it motivates, proposes and evaluates a new regularizer term that promotes smoothness via enforcing the representation to be geometry-preserving (isometry, conformal mapping of degree k). Comparisons with a standard VAE and FMVAE (Chen et al. 2020) are shown and experiments are provided on CelebA with several different attributes as target classification tasks. The paper has received extensive reviews and the authors have successfully answered most of the concerns raised, mostly regarding comparisons to other techniques that try to introduce a regularization based on the properties of the Jacobian of the decoder network. The appendix has been extended as a result of
column2: This paper proposes a method to learn representations by using a multi-task learning method. The proposed method is well-motivated and the experimental results are strong. The reviewers agree that the paper is well motivated, well-written and well motivated. The main concerns raised by the reviewers have been addressed by the authors in the rebuttal. The authors are encouraged to incorporate the reviewers' comments in the final version of the paper.

column1: The article proposes an approach to alter the approximate posterior distribution in order to remove some of the information (unlearning). The approach is applicable when the approximate posterior is obtained via (stochastic gradient) MCMC methods. Unlearning is done by shifting the approximate true posterior by some value delta, which is found via optimisation with an influence function. The approach is novel, tackles an important problem and is mathematically sound. Reviewers have highlighted some of its limitations. It is non-trivial, the empirical evaluations and theoretical analysis are rigorous, resulting in a novel method that produces near optimal policies from more readily available demonstrations. The authors revised the manuscript to reflect the reviewers' comments.

Experiments show that the proposed method can perform better than the baseline methods. The paper is well written and well written, though the experiments point out that there are a number of issues that need to be addressed. The authors have addressed most of the concerns raised by reviewers.

column2: This paper proposes a method for self-supervised adversarial learning. The proposed method is based on a learning algorithm that uses a classifier to select the input of the target domain to be labeled in the source domain. It is shown that the proposed algorithm can be understood as a linearization algorithm that minimizes the square of the distance between the input and target domain. The paper is well-written, well-motivated and is well motivated. The main concern is that the authors propose a method that is not well understood. The authors are not clear on the novelty of the proposed method, but the reviewers are in agreement that it is an interesting contribution to the field.

Instead of adding an explicit regularizer to encourage this, authors propose an optimization algorithm called Fish which implicitly encourages higher inner-product between gradients of different domains. Authors further show their proposed method is competitive on challenging benchmarks such as WILDS and DomainBed. Reviewers all found the proposed algorithm novel and expressed that the contributions of the paper in terms of improving domain generalization is significant. The reviewers agreed that the proposed approach is not well evaluated, but the empirical results are still impressive. Overall, I agree with the reviewers that this paper is a solid contribution.

The reviewers engaged in significant discussion around the paper with many iterations of improvements to the paper. Initial concerns regarding zero-shot learning were addressed, as were remarks on presentation and claims. In the end the reviewers were split on this paper. I recommend to accept the paper on the basis of the semantic topology ideas and the thorough experimental results. The proposed approach is based on an approach based on the VQD model, which is a method that is very simple. The paper is well written and the experimental results are thorough. The reviewers agree that the paper is interesting, well-written and well-motivated. There are some concerns about the simplicity of the approach and the lack of clarity in the experiments. column1: The paper addresses a few very important points on sequential latent-variable models, and introduce a different view on meta-RL. Even though the methods that this paper poses are incremental, it is such a hot-debated topic that I would prefer to see this published now.
column2: This paper proposes a method to learn to learn the temporal dynamics of a robot. The proposed method uses deep nets to encode the latent data of a latent variables and a latent agent, which is then applied to a global model of the robot. It is shown that the proposed method is efficient and can be used to learn an agent-based reinforcement learning algorithm. The reviewers are in agreement that this is an interesting contribution to the field of reinforcement learning. The paper is well-written and well-motivated, and the reviewers are encouraged to accept the paper.

Two reviewers think that the fact the results are not competitive with the best non-learning-based ("classic") solvers mean that the paper should be rejected. There were some concerns about the novelty of the paper, and the clarity of the results. The main concern raised by the reviewers was the lack of experimental evaluation of the approach.

Initially, there was some concern about the size of the validation set, which is addressed by the rebuttal. Consolidating the reviews and rebuttals, the meta-reviewer agrees with the assessment of the reviewers and would like to recommend acceptance of the paper.

The reviewers agree that the paper is well-written, well-motivated and the experimental results are clear. There are some concerns about the novelty of the approach, and that the experiments and baselines are not comprehensive. The paper is a solid contribution to the field of generative models.

The work follows the line of research in which model size is reduced by decomposing the matrices in the model into smaller factors. Two-step approaches apply SVD and then fine-tuned the model on task specific data. The present work makes the observation that after the first step (the SVD compression) the model can dramatically lose its performance, due to the mismatched optimization objectives between the low-rank approximation and the target task. column1: This paper develops a ``preference-conditioned” approach to approximate the Pareto frontier for Multi-Objective Combinatorial Optimization (MOCO) problems with a single model (thus dealing with the thorny problem that there can be exponentially-many Pareto-optimal solutions). It appears to provide flexibility for users to obtain various preferred tradeoffs between the objectives without extra search. The basic idea is to use end-to-end RL to train the single model for all different preferences simultaneously. The technical soundness and practical performance are strong. Based on a causal graph of the adversarial data creation process, which describes the perceived data as a function of content and style variables, the authors identified that the spurious correlation between style and label is the main reason for adversarial examples. Based on this observation, they propose a method to learn models for which the conditional distribution of label given style and image does not vary much when attacked. The reviewers are generally positive about the paper, with some concerns about the novelty and novelty of the approach. The main concerns are that the authors have not provided examples of the adversarial examples that the proposed method is robust to, which prior work is not.

At the same time, the architect determines what is "sensible" by building a model of the builder's behavior and planning over it. The paper proposes an approach called cross-lingual manifold mixup, which uses a mixup between the source and target language data. There are some concerns about the novelty of the approach, and the paper also is not clear that the proposed method can be used in many different tasks. Overall, I agree that this paper is a solid contribution to the conference.
