column2: This paper proposes a method to learn a model based on the advantage-based policy learning method, using an encoder to learn the policy of the agent. The proposed method is evaluated on multiple datasets in multiple environments. The reviewers agreed that the paper is well-written and well-motivated, and the experimental results are impressive. The authors did a good job in the discussion phase, and provided a thorough rebuttal. The main concerns raised by the reviewers were the novelty of the method, the novelty and the clarity of the presentation. The AC agrees with the reviewers that the authors should make the paper more clear.

column1: This paper received 5 quality reviews, with 3 of them rated 8, 1 rated 6, and 1 rated 5. In general, while there are minor concerns, the reviewers acknowledge the contribution of applying Knowledge distillation to the problem of monocular 3D object detection, and appreciate the SOTA performance on the KITTI validation and test sets. The AC concurs with these important contributions and recommends acceptance.
column2: This paper proposes a method to learn 3D objects from a set of images. The main contribution is to use object-features that are important for the 3D object detection. The paper also proposes a new method to address the concern that the goal of the paper is to learn 2D objects. The reviewers were generally positive about the paper, with some concerns about the novelty and novelty of the proposed approach. The authors did a good job in the rebuttal, and provided a thorough rebuttal. The AC agrees with the reviewers that the paper was well-written and well-motivated.

column1: There are numerous known methods for memory reduction used in CNNs. This paper takes two such---quantization (Q) and random projection (RP)---and applies them to GNNs. This is a novelty, but I agree with the reviewers: on its own this novelty would not be "surprising" enough to report at ICLR. The paper further goes to show empirically that these methods, when applied to a reasonable set of datasets, do indeed produce their predicted memory reductions (unsurprising) with a small ( ≈0.5% ) drop in accuracy (surprising, in the sense of not being something one could predict without doing the experiment). All
column2: This paper studies the problem of reducing the computational cost of training graph convolutional neural network models. The reviewers agreed that the paper is well-written, well-motivated, and the proposed method is novel. The main concerns raised by the reviewers are that the method is relatively simple, and that the authors have addressed some of the concerns of the reviewers. The authors provided a thorough empirical evaluation and theoretical analysis of the approach, and provided a comprehensive empirical study of the cost and efficiency of the method. The AC-GC paper is an interesting contribution to the literature that would be interesting to accept.

column1: The authors first consider a mean field two player zero sum game and consider quasistatic Wasserstein gradient flow dynamics for solving the problem. The dynamics is proved to be convergent under some assumptions. Finally, the authors provide a discretization of the gradient flow and using this proposes an algorithm for solving min-max optimization problems. They use this algorithm for GAN's as the main example. Experimental results claim that the algorithm outperforms langevin gradient descent especially in high dimensionas. This paper sits right at the border. But subsequent to the author response, one of the reviewers has updated the score and seems more positive about the paper. In view of this, I am
column2: This paper proposes a new method to learn how to estimate the convergence of a Gaussian distribution of the permutation of the probability function of the Nash equilibrium. The paper is well written with clear theoretical and empirical results. The authors provide an interesting and novel contribution to the field of GANs, and show that the problem can be solved well. The reviewers were generally positive about the paper, with some concerns about the novelty and novelty of the proposed method. The main concerns raised by the reviewers were that the paper is not clear and the experiments are not thorough.

column1: This paper proposes an extension of CTC by considering the wild-card to adjust the label missing issues during training. The authors propose to minimize the loss over all possible sub-segments of the input to automatically align the one that matches the available transcript. It is empirically proved to significantly improve performance over CTC even if up to 40-70% label sequence is missed (overall performance similar to the complete label case) across different tasks. As agreed by the reviewers, the paper is well presented and the problem is interesting to a broad community. Dynamic time warping with unconstrained endpoints itself is not a new idea and a classical topic for speech recognition (e. g
column2: This paper presents a method for learning to learn to map a set of unsupervised token labels from a large dataset. The paper is well-written, well-motivated, and the experimental performance is strong. The authors also addressed the concerns raised by reviewers and addressed the questions raised by the reviewers in the rebuttal phase of the paper.

column1: This paper tackles a bandit problem that incorporates three challenges motivated by common issues encountered in online recommender systems: delayed reward, incentivized exploration, and self-reinforcing user preference. The authors propose an approach called UCB-Filtering-with-Delayed-Feedback (UCB-FDF) for this problem and provide a theoretical analysis showing that UCB-FDF achieves the optimal regret bounds. Their analysis also implies that logarithmic regret and incentive cost growth rates are achievable under this setting. These theoretical results are supported by empirical experiments, e. g. using Amazon review data. The main concern with this paper is that the considered challenges have all been
column2: This paper studies the problem setting and theoretical analysis of a method for improving the performance of an agent based on a policy where the policy has a finite number of actions. The authors propose a method to learn how to use the policy to improve the accuracy of the agent. The main concern of the paper is that it is not clear to me how the actions of the policy can benefit the algorithm. The paper is well-written with a thorough rebuttal, and the authors have addressed most of the reviewers' concerns.

column1: Reviewers agreed that this work is well-motivated and presents a novel approach for data augmentation around the adaptive augmentation policies. There were some concerns around the lack of ablation studies and unclear performance improvements, which were addressed well by the authors’ responses. Thus, I recommend an acceptance.
column2: This paper proposes a method to learn a class-dependent and a subgroup-dependent augmentation policy for a dataset. The paper is well-written and well-motivated, and the experimental results are impressive. The reviewers have some concerns about the novelty of the approach and the performance of the proposed method. Overall, the paper is above the acceptance threshold for acceptance. I recommend acceptance.

column1: The paper received two accept and two marginally accept recommendations. All reviewers find value in the proposed supervised semantic segmentation methodology (making self-supervised representation learning towards dense prediction tasks like segmentation or clustering without explicit manual supervision) and appreciate the experimental gains, but had (mostly practical) criticism that was reasonably well addressed in the rebuttal.
column2: This paper proposes a method to learn to learn graph convolutional representations of objects from a number of images. The proposed method is based on the DIDE model, which is an adversarial model of the visual representation of objects. The reviewers agreed that the paper is well-written, well-motivated and the method is sound. The main concerns raised by the reviewers were the novelty of the proposed method, and the simplicity of the approach. The authors did a good job in addressing reviewers' concerns about the novelty, and addressed most of them in the rebuttal.

column1: The initial reviews for this paper were 6,6,6, the authors have provided a rebuttal and after the rebuttal the recommendation stayed the same. The reviewers have reached the consensus that the paper is borderline but they have all recommended keeping it above the acceptance threshold. Following the recommendation of the reviewers, the meta reviewer recommends acceptance.
column2: This paper proposes a method for learning to learn to predict the representation of images from a set of images. The proposed approach is based on the neural architecture of the graph, which is a neural architecture based on gradient descent learning. The paper is well-written and well-motivated, and the experimental results show that the approach is interesting and novel. The reviewers agreed that the paper was interesting and the authors did a good job in the rebuttal. The main concerns raised by the reviewers have been addressed by the authors in the revised version.

column1: This paper proposes to leverage topological structure between domains, expressed as a graph, towards solving the domain adaptation problem. Reviewer n4Lk thought the ideas were interesting, appreciated the theoretical analysis and indicated that the experiments were “well thought out”. The reviewer asked for more detail on Lemma 4.1 and suggested that a proof be provided for Proposition 4.1. They asked for more justification on why the change of task for the discriminator from classification to generation would improve performance. The authors responded to these comments, clarifying the proof of Lemma 4.1 in the appendix. They clarified that proposition 4.1 can be derived from Corollary 4.
column2: This paper proposes a novel method for multi-target domain adaptation. The authors provide a theoretical analysis that is clear and clear-motivated. The experimental results show the effectiveness of the proposed method on domain ablation. The reviewers agree that the paper is well-written and the experimental results are convincing. The main concerns raised by the reviewers are that the authors have not provided a thorough analysis of the empirical results.

column1: This paper studies structured pruning methods, called kernel-pruning in the paper which is also known as channel pruning for convolutional kernels. A simple method is proposed that primarily consists of three stages: (i) clusters the filters in a convolution layer into predefined number of groups, (ii) prune the unimportant kernels from each group, and (iii) permute remaining kernels to form a grouped convolution operation and then fine-tune the network. Although the novelty of the method is not high, it is simple and effective in experiments after the supplementary sota results in the long rebuttal. Majority of reviewers increase their ratings after the rebuttal (though
column2: The paper proposes a method to learn the maximum square function of a class of the training data. The paper is well-written and well-motivated. The experimental results are not clear and the empirical evaluation is not clear. The authors have addressed the concerns raised by the reviewers by adding additional experiments.

column1: This paper proposes a new bilinear decomposition for universal value functions. The bilinear network has one component dependent on state and goal and another component that depends on state and action. The experiments with the DDPG algorithm in robot simulations show that the proposed architecture improves performance data efficiency and task transfer over several baseline algorithms, including improvements on earlier bilinear decompositions. The reviews noted several aspects of the paper could be improved, and the author response addressed several of these concerns. Multiple reviewers appreciated the insights from the experiment added in section 4.5 on a simple grid environment, which enabled a direct interpretation of the vector fields used in the method. Several aspects of the presentation
column2: This paper proposes a new method for learning a model based on the representation of the state of an agent. The proposed model is based on a neural network with a global component that depends on goal and state and a local component that uses action and action representation. The authors also propose a method for training the model with a set of training parameters. The reviewers agreed that the paper is well-written and well-motivated. The main concerns raised by the reviewers were about the novelty of the proposed method and the experimental evaluation of the method. There was a consensus that the authors did a good job in the rebuttal.

column1: This well written and well motivated paper has been independently reviewed by four expert reviewers. They all voted for the acceptance with three straight accepts and one marginal. The feedback provided to authors was constructive and the authors responded comprehensively. I recommend acceptance of this work for ICLR.
column2: This paper proposes a new method to learn how to learn the more diverse representations that are shown to perform better on image-Net. The reviewers agreed that the paper is well-written and the experiments are thorough, and the authors provided a thorough analysis of the experimental results. The main concerns raised by the reviewers are that the authors did not address some of the questions raised by reviewers, and that the experiments were not thorough. The authors also provided some clarifications and clarifications about the authors' response to reviewers' concerns.

column1: The focus of the paper is kernel thinning, i. e. the extraction of a core set from a sample with good integration properties meant in MMD (maximum mean discrepancy, hence worst case) sense. Particularly, the authors propose generalizations of the kernel thinning method (Dwivedi and Mackey, 2021) which relax the assumptions imposed on the kernel (k) and the target distribution (P), and possess tighter performance guarantees. Designing compressed representation of samples for integration is a fundamental problem in machine learning and statistics with a large number of successful applications. As assessed by the reviewers, the authors deliver important new theoretical insights in the area which can be also of clear practical
column2: This paper proposes a new method to improve the accuracy of the log-normalization algorithm. The paper is well-written and well-motivated, with a clear and clear motivation of the problem. The reviewers agree that the paper is hard to follow, and that the novelty of the work is not clear. The authors did a good job in the discussion phase, and all reviewers agreed that the work should be accepted. There were some concerns about the clarity of the paper, and the simplicity of the results.

column1: Reviewers are in agreement that this work is a useful, clear, documentary piece of work that shows the utility of CLIP on a number of popular V+L tasks. There is a somewhat persistent concern that simply demonstrating that a stronger visual encoder leads to improvements downstream is not an insightful result on which the community can build.
column2: This paper studies the ability of the VQA, VLN, and VLT models to improve the performance of vision and language tasks. The reviewers found that the authors did not provide clear evidence of the effectiveness of the proposed methods. The authors also found that some of the models are not accessible as of 2020, and the authors provided some clarifications. The paper is well-motivated, well-written, and well-done. The main concerns raised by the reviewers have been addressed by the authors.

column1: The paper studies gradient descent for matrix factorization with a learning rate that is large relative to the a certain notion of the scale of the problem. In particular, they show that the use of large learning rates leads to balancing between the two factors in the factorization. The discussion between the authors and the reviewers was fruitful in dispelling some of the reviewers' doubts and at the same time improving the paper. The paper seems to make some contribution on a relevant problem for the ICLR community. However, even in the restricted settings they consider, the problem does not appear to be completely solved. That said, I agree with the majority of the reviewers that the step forward seems enough to warrant
column2: This paper presents a theoretical analysis of the theorems of neural network optimization. The reviewers agreed that the paper is well-written and well-motivated. There were some concerns about the novelty of the theoretical analysis and the clarity of the results. The authors did a good job in addressing the concerns raised by the reviewers. The main concern was that the authors did not provide sufficient evidence of the theory and experiments in the paper.

column1: This paper explores why adversarial examples do not transfer well in adversarial examples on automatic speech recognition systems. The authors propose a number of potential causes that are then quickly evaluated in turn. This could be an excellent paper, but in its current form, it is borderline. The main problem with the paper is that it proposes a number of causes for the limited transferability, and then evaluates each of them with one quick experiment and just a paragraph of text. In particular, none of the results actually convince me that the claim is definitely correct, and many of the experimental setups are confusing or would have other explanations other than the one variable that is aiming to be controlled for. That said, even
column2: This paper studies an important problem and provides valuable insights into the very low target transferability between ASR models. The reviewers agreed that the paper is well-written and well-motivated. The authors did a good job in addressing the problem of the limited adversarial transferability in ASR systems. There were some concerns about the novelty of the approach, and the experiments on the input distribution are not very interesting to me.

column1: The paper proposes PipeGCN, a system that uses pipeline parallelism to accelerate distributed training of large-scale graph convolutional neural networks. Like some pipeline-parallel methods (but unlike others), PipeGCN involves asynchrony in the sense that its features and feature-gradients can be stale. The paper provides theoretical guarantees on the convergence of PipeGCN in the presence of this staleness, which is a nice contribution in itself. In discussion, the reviewers found the work to be well-executed and sound. All reviewers recommended acceptance, and I concur with this consensus.
column2: This paper proposes a method to learn graph neural network training on large graphs using a graph representation. The proposed method is based on self-supervised neural network learning, which is an approach for learning graph neural networks. The authors show that the proposed method achieves a 2.2x speedup on a number of datasets. The paper is well-written and well-motivated, and the experimental results are thorough. The main concern is the novelty of the method, and it is not clear that the method can be used on the large dataset.

column1: This paper studies the design and analysis of contextual bandits algorithms, combining the ideas of neural network models (Zhou et al, 2020 and Zhang et al, 2020) and reward perturbations (Kveton et al, 2019, 2020); this has the computational advantage of avoiding inverting large covariance matrices, as is done in the other neural contextual bandits algorithms. Although the reviewers think that the papers need to do a better job in highlighting differences and extra challenges in the current work compared to prior works, they also acknowledge that this paper is the first that combines the above two ideas. The reviewers also acknowledge that the additional experiments in the rebuttal period help clear the concern the reviewers
column2: This paper proposes a method for learning a neural network with a finite number of agents. The proposed algorithm is based on the neural network as well as the training of the network. The authors propose a method to improve the performance of the proposed algorithm. The reviewers agreed that the paper is well-motivated and well-written. The main concerns raised by the reviewers were about the novelty of the method and the novelty in the results. The AC agrees that the proposed method is novel and the experiments show that it can be applied to a number of practical applications.

column1: This paper investigates defense against backdoor attacks for models that have already been trained. It proposes, in particular, a min-max formulation for backdoor defense, in which the inner maximum seeks a powerful trigger that leads to a high loss, while the outer minimum seeks to suppress the "adversarial loss", so as to unlearn the injected backdoor behaviors. To solve the minimax, the authors also propose a method, Implicit Backdoor Adversarial Unlearning (I-BAU). In addition, the authors also provide theoretical analysis including the convergence bound and generalization bound. Extensive experiments demonstrate the effectiveness and efficiency of the proposed method. The proposed method is interesting and the implementation is
column2: This paper proposes a method to tackle adversarial adversarial learning with adversarial perturbation. The reviewers found the paper well-written and well-motivated, and the proposed algorithm is simple to understand. Overall, the reviewers had some concerns about the novelty of the approach and the efficiency of the proposed method. The authors did a good job in the rebuttal and addressed most of the concerns raised by the reviewers. The AC agrees with the reviewers that the proposed approach is novel and interesting.

column1: This paper concerns ensemble methods in deep reinforcement learning, examining several such methods, and proposes to address an important issue wherein ensemble members converge on a representation of approximately the same function, either by their parameters converging to an identical point or equivalent points that give rise to the same function. The authors propose a set of regularization methods aimed at improving diversity, and benchmark these augmentations on five ensemble methods and a dozen environments. 3 of 4 reviewers generally praised the method's simplicity and generality, and found the experiments convincing. Reviewer a9sA describes it as "clearly written and easy to follow", although others found clarity lacking in parts. There was agreement among these 3 reviewers that
column2: This paper proposes a method to learn the policy of an agent using an ensemble of agents. The authors show that the performance of the approach is outperforming existing methods. The paper is well-written, well-motivated, and the experiments are thorough. The reviewers agree that the paper is interesting and the experimental results are impressive. The main concerns raised by the reviewers have been addressed in the rebuttal phase.

column1: This work adds the positional encoding (akin to those in transformers, but adapted) to GNNs. In their reviews, reviewers raised a number of concerns about this work, in particular, lack of novelty, lack of ablations to demonstrate the claims of the paper, lack of comparison to previous work (e. g., position-aware GNNS, Graphormer and GraphiT which would appear very related to this work), lack of motivation (e. g., the introduced positional loss do not actually improve performance), and whether the experimental results were really significant. During the rebuttal, the authors replied to the reviews, to address. the concerns that they could. Of
column2: This paper studies the problem of how to use structure information in graph neural networks. The paper proposes a method to incorporate latent embeddings into graph convolutional neural networks, and a way to encode the embedders into the graph. The reviewers agree that the paper is well-motivated, well-written and well-done. The main concern is that the novelty of the paper's approach is limited, and the experiments are not clear. Overall, the paper was a solid contribution to the conference.

column1: The paper considers the problem of accelerated magnetic resonance imaging where the goal is to reconstruct an image from undersampled measurements. The paper proposes a zero-shot self-supervised learning approach for accelerated deep learning based magnetic resonance imaging. The approach partitions the measurements from a single scan into two disjoint sets, one set is used for self-supervised learning, and one set is used to perform validation, specifically to select a regularization parameter. The set that is used for self-supervised learning is then again split into two different sets, and a network is trained to predict the frequencies from one set based on the frequencies in the other set. This enables accelerated MRI without any training
column2: This paper proposes a method to learn to train a model on a large batch of images and train the model on the source data. The proposed method is based on the idea of zero-shot learning, which is not new. The paper is well-written and well-motivated, and the experimental results are impressive. The reviewers agree that the paper is of interest, and that the proposed approach is interesting and novel. The main concerns raised by the reviewers are that the experiments are not thorough and the empirical results are not clear. The authors have addressed these concerns in the rebuttal phase.

column1: The reviewers appreciated the treatment of the topic of certifiable robustness done in this work and although they had a number of concerns, I feel they were adequately addressed by the authors.
column2: This paper proposes a new method to improve robustness of reinforcement learning models. The reviewers agreed that the paper is well-written and well-motivated, and the experimental results are strong. The authors did a good job in addressing the concerns raised by the reviewers. The main concern raised by reviewers was the novelty of the proposed method, which is a novel contribution to the field of RL. Overall, the reviewers found the paper to be well written and clear.

column1: This paper was borderline, based on the reviews. The paper points out an interesting connection (somewhat known but not in this specific version) and good experimental results. However, numerous reviewers raised concerns that the paper was lacking a comparison to prior work connecting unsupervised learning and meta-learning, most notably, Hsu et al. (2019). After reading the revised version of the paper, the authors address this issue and also all the other reviewer comments. In relation to prior work they clarify that they focus on the contrastive unsupervised case and also do a good job in answering other reviewer concerns relative to novelty and results. I would also like to point out, as reviewers
column2: This paper studies the problem of how to use meta-learning to improve the performance of self-supervised learning on a variety of tasks. The reviewers agreed that the paper is well-written and well-motivated. The main concerns raised by the reviewers were the novelty of the paper, and the lack of comparison to other work on the problem. The authors also raised concerns about the use of the work in terms of image classification, which is an important problem in the context of vision detection and vision detection.

column1: The main contribution is a way of analyzing the generalization error of neural nets by breaking it down into bias and variance components, and using separate principles to analyze each of the two components. The submission first proves rigorous generalization bounds for overparameterized linear regression (motivated in a general sense by the NTK); there are settings where this improves upon existing bounds. It extends the case to a matrix recovery model, showing that it's not limited to the linear regime. Finally, experimental results show that the risk decomposition holds empirically for neural nets. The numerical scores would place this paper slightly below the cutoff. The reviewers feel that the paper is well written and have not identified anything
column2: This paper studies the problem of how to estimate the loss of a neural network from the input data. The authors introduce a method to encode the loss in the output of the neural network. The paper is well-written, well-motivated and well-done. The reviewers agree that the paper is very interesting and clear. There are some concerns about the novelty of the paper, and the clarity of the writing.

column1: The paper proposes a novel approach to graph representation learning. In particular, a graph auto-encoder is proposed that aims to better capture the topological structure by utilising a neighbourhood reconstruction and a degree reconstruction objective. An optimal-transport based objective is proposed for the neighbourhood reconstruction that optimises the 2-Wasserstein distance between the decoded distribution and an empirical estimate of the neighbourhood distribution. An extensive experimental analysis is performed, highlighting the benefits of the proposed approach on a range of synthetic datasets to capture structure information. The experimental results also highlight its robustness across 9 different real-world graph datasets (ranging from proximity-oriented to structure-oriented datasets). Strengths: -
column2: This paper studies the problem of training a graph encoder in the context of the graph embedding of graph data. The paper proposes a method to learn a graph in a supervised environment. The reviewers agreed that the paper is well-motivated, well-written and the experimental results are impressive. There were some concerns about the novelty of the proposed method and the simplicity of the experiments. The authors provided a thorough rebuttal to the reviewers' concerns and provided additional experimental results on several datasets.

column1: All reviewers agree that the presented approach to fair calibration of face verification models is interesting and needed in the field. The method does not require access to sensitive attributes for calibrating, which makes it sustainable. The reviewers are satisfied with the presented experimental studies in most cases. The rebuttal addressed a large majority of additionally raised questions. I believe that the paper will be of interest to the audience attending ICLR and would recommend a presentation of the work as a poster.
column2: This paper proposes a method to tackle the problem of weakness of classifiers with respect to demographic classes. The authors show that the method is a simple, efficient, and efficient approach for training the classifiers. The paper is well-written, well-motivated, and well-done. The reviewers were generally positive about the paper, with some concerns about the novelty of the work. The main concerns raised by the reviewers were that the paper is not clear to the authors, and that the experiments are not thorough, and the authors should address these concerns.

column1: The paper presents a domain adaptation approach based on the importance weighting for unsupervised cross-lingual learning. The paper first analyzes factors that affect cross-lingual transfer and finds that the cross-lingual transfer performance is strongly correlated with feature representation alignments as well as the distributional shift in class priors between the source and the target. Then the paper designs an approach based on the observations. Pros: + The paper is well written and the proposed approach is well motivated. + The analysis about which factors affect cross-lingual transfer is interesting and provides some great insight. Cons: - As the reviewer pointed out, the experiments for verifying the proposed approach are relatively weak
column2: This paper studies the problem of cross-lingual transfer as a domain transfer problem, which is an existing problem. The reviewers agreed that the paper is interesting, and the authors provided a thorough rebuttal. The main concern raised by the reviewers is that the reviewers are not fully convinced about the novelty of the paper and the effectiveness of the proposed approach. The authors did a good job in responding to the reviewers' concerns, and addressed most of them in their response. The AC agrees with the reviewers and recommends acceptance.

column1: This paper proposes a new dataset called ComPhy to evaluate the ability of models to infer physical properties of objects and to reason about their interactions given these physical properties. The paper also presents an oracle model (named oracle because it requires gold property labels at training time) that is modular and carefully hand designed, but shows considerable improvement over a series of baselines. The reviewers for this submission had several concerns including: (a) [VByS] "concerns are about the complexity that the proposed method can handle"\ (b) [VByS] "the method is only demonstrated on a simple synthetic dataset"\ (c) [8BUA] "
column2: This paper proposes a method to learn how to learn the relationship between a set of objects and an agent. The proposed method is evaluated on a dataset with a number of real-world objects, and a variety of real world tasks. The reviewers agree that the paper is well-written and well-motivated, and the proposed dataset is novel and novel. The main concerns are about the complexity that the proposed method can tackle and the novelty of the approach. The authors also found that the method is not very simple, and it is not clear that it can be generalized to other domains. The paper is also well written and well motivated, and is well motivated.

column1: To tackle the problem of classification under input-dependent noise, the authors proposed the posterior transition matrix (PTM) to achieve statistically consistent classification. Specifically the information fusion approach was developed to fine-tune the noise transition matrix. Experiments demonstrated the effectiveness of the proposed approach. I would like to thank the authors for the detailed feedback to the initial reviews and also further feedback to the reviewers' additional questions. Many concerns were clarified by the feedback, and the additional experiments still demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method. The issue of data augmentation still remains, which should be at least experimentally investigated, but the contribution of the current manuscript is still valuable to be presented as ICLR
column2: This paper proposes a new method for learning with noisy labels. The paper proposes an interesting contribution to the field of object detection in vision. The reviewers agree that the paper is well-written and well-motivated. The main concerns raised by the reviewers are the novelty of the approach and the lack of experimental results. The authors are encouraged to incorporate the reviewers' feedback in the paper.

column1: This paper makes the important, albeit somewhat unsurprising, finding, that cell-based NAS search spaces, and in particular the DARTS search space, include some operations that are much better than others. Reducing the search space to these allows even random architectures to yield good performance, similarly to the findings of "Designing Network Design Spaces", https://openaccess. thecvf. com/content_CVPR_2020/html/Radosavovic_Designing_Network_Design_Spaces_CVPR_2020_paper. html This paper received mostly positive scores (5,6,6,8). While I agree with the negative reviewer that it would be good
column2: This paper studies the problem of how to learn how to estimate the performance of neural networks from the input data. The reviewers agreed that the paper is well-written and the results are interesting and novel. The main concern was that the authors did not address the concerns raised by the reviewers. The authors did a good job in the rebuttal and addressed most of the concerns in the reviewers' feedback. Overall, the reviewers found the paper well written and clear and the reviewers had some concerns about the novelty of the results.

column1: This paper seeks to find an answer to some quite interesting research question: can deep vanilla networks without skip connections or normalization layers be trained as fast and accurately as ResNets? In this regard, the authors extend Deep Kernel Shaping and show that a vanilla network with leaky RELU-family activations can match the performance of a deep residual network. Four reviewers unanimously suggested acceptance of the paper. There were concerns about the clarity or marginal performance improvement. However, they all including myself agree: achieving the competitive performance with the vanilla deep model itself can be seen as a big contribution and the clarity has been improved to some extent through revision.
column2: This paper proposes a method to improve the performance of deep neural networks. The paper is well-written and well-motivated. The reviewers were generally positive about the paper, with the remaining concerns raised by the reviewers. The authors did a good job in addressing reviewers' concerns about the novelty of the proposed method, and addressed most of them.

column1: The paper analyzes the behavior of VAEs in modeling data lying on a low dimensional manifold. It formally proves some of the conjectures/informal-statements in an earlier work by Dai and Wipf (2019) in the case of linear VAE and linear manifold, and disproves the same for the nonlinear case. In particular, it proves, by analyzing the objective and its gradient-flow dynamics, that VAE captures the intrinsic dimension of data distribution correctly. For nonlinear cases, the paper shows a counterexample to the conjecture in (Dai & Wipf; 2019) where the support of VAE generators is a superset of that
column2: This paper presents a theoretical analysis of the convergence properties of a neural network, which is an important research area. The reviewers agree that the paper is well-written, well-motivated and well-done. The main concerns raised by the reviewers are the novelty of the paper, and the lack of clarity of the theoretical results. The authors have provided a thorough rebuttal to the reviewers' comments, and all reviewers are satisfied with the paper's contributions.

column1: The paper observes that the number of redundant parameters is a function of the training procedure and proposes a training strategy that encourages all parameters in the model to be trained sufficiently and become useful. The method adaptively adjusts the learning rate for each individual parameter according to its sensitivity (a proxy for the parameter's contribution to the model performance). The approach encourages the use of under fitted parameters while preventing overfitting in the well-fitted ones. Experimental results are presented covering a wide range of tasks and in combination with several optimisers, showing improvements in model generalization. The paper is very well written and easy to follow (as mentioned by Reviewers NSqH, 4pzE and sSHP
column2: This paper studies the problem of how to learn a model with a large number of parameters. The reviewers agreed that the paper is well-written and well-motivated. There were some concerns about the novelty of the method, and the simplicity of the approach. Overall, the reviewers found the paper to be above the acceptance threshold. The authors did a good job addressing the concerns raised by the reviewers.
