There are some concerns about the novelty of the proposed method, and the clarity of the results. The authors are encouraged to address these concerns in the revision.

column1: This article introduces an interesting variant of the work of Nakkiran & Bansal (2020). It shows empirically that the test error of deep models can be approximated from the disagreement on the unlabelled test data between two different trainings on the same data. The authors then show theoretically that a calibration property can explain such behaviour, and they report experiments showing that the relationship does exist in practical situations. All reviewers agree on the practical and theoretical value of the article, which is very well organised and written. The ideas developed here are likely to lead to further work in the future, and they clearly deserve to be published at ICLR. I agree with one of the reviewers
column2: This paper shows strong theoretical and empirical results that are novel and novel. The paper is well-written and well-motivated, and the experiments are thorough and clear. The authors have provided a theoretical connection between generalization and calibration. The reviewers agreed that the paper is interesting and novel, and that the authors should be accepted. There were some concerns about the novelty of the results and the clarity of the theoretical analysis, but the authors addressed these concerns in the rebuttal.

column1: This paper proposes an alternative approach to epsilon-greedy exploration by instead generating multi-step plans from an RNN, and then stochastically determining whether to continue with the plan or re-plan. The reviewers agreed that this idea is novel and interesting, that the paper is well-written, and that the evaluations are convincing, showing large improvements over epsilon-greedy exploration and more consistently strong performance than other baselines. While the original reviews contained some questions around discussion of related work and the simplicity of the evaluation environments, the reviewers felt these concerns were adequately addressed by the rebuttal. I agree the paper explores a very interesting idea and convincingly demonstrates its potential
column2: This paper studies the problem of how to learn to learn from the perspective of planning for exploration. The reviewers agreed that the paper is well-written and well-motivated. The main concerns raised by the reviewers are that the reviewers found the paper to be well written, the experiments strong, and the experimental results convincing. The authors did a good job in the rebuttal, with the main concerns about the experiments and the presentation that were addressed by the authors.

column1: This paper makes significant advances in offline reinforcement learning by proposing a new approach of being pessimistic to deal with uncertainties in the offline data. The proposed approach uses bootstrapped Q-functions to quantify the uncertainty, which by itself is not new, and introduces additional data based on the pseudo-target that is penalized by the uncertainty quantification. The use of such additional data is the first of a kind, and the paper provides theoretical support for the case of linear MDP and empirical support with the D4RL benchmark. The reviewers had originally raised concerns or confusions regarding theoretical analysis and experiments. The authors have well responded to them, and no major concerns remain.
column2: This paper proposes a method to learn policy-based reinforcement learning by training the model on a number of environments. The paper is well-written and well-motivated, and the proposed method outperforms existing methods. The reviewers agreed that the paper is a solid contribution to the area of RL. The authors did a good job in addressing the concerns raised by reviewers, and I recommend acceptance.

column1: Improving the expressiveness of GNN is an important problem in the current graph learning community. Its key idea is to generate subgraphs from the original graph, then encode the subgraphs into the message passing process of GNN. The proposed method is proven to be strictly more powerful than 1-WL. The authors also quantize how design choices such as the subgraph selection policy and equivariant neural architecture can affect the architecture’s expressive power. After the rebuttal, all reviewers are glad to accept this submission. During the discussion, while reviewer B3oK has shown some concerns on the concurrent works in NeurIPS 2021, it should not affect the
column2: This paper proposes a method to learn graph representation learning by learning from a set of subgraphs. The proposed method is well-written and well-motivated, and the experimental results are thorough and thorough. The experimental results show that the proposed method performs better than previous methods on a number of datasets. The reviewers agree that the approach is interesting, well-done and novel. The main concerns raised by the reviewers are that the method is relatively simple and the experiments are limited. The authors are encouraged to address these concerns in the rebuttal.

column1: The paper presents an empirical analysis of Vision Transformers - and in particular multi-headed self-attention - and ConvNets, with a focus on optimization-related properties (loss landscape, Hessian eigenvalues). The paper shows that both classes of models have their strengths and weaknesses and proposes a hybrid model that takes the best of both worlds and demonstrates good empirical performance. Reviewers are mostly very positive about the paper. Main pro is that analysis is important and this paper does a thorough job at it and draws some useful insights. There are several smaller issues with the presentation and the details of the content, but the authors did a good job addressing these in their responses. Overall, it
column2: This paper proposes a new architecture that is more robust and effective on imageNet and ImageNet and CIFAR-100 datasets. The paper is well-written, well-motivated and well-done, with thorough empirical results and evidence. The reviewers agreed that the paper is a solid contribution to the field. The authors did a good job in addressing an important problem and providing interesting insights. The main concerns raised by the reviewers were the clarity of the experiments and the lack of clarifications in the presentation of the results. Overall, the reviewers found the paper to be an interesting and well motivated contribution.

column1: The authors propose a well-presented approach to likelihood-free inference. The reviewers are all in alignment in recommending this paper for acceptance. There was a healthy discussion between authors and reviewers, where the authors have already incorporated many of their recommendations. The potential for this methodology to be applied to situations with expensive simulators should be intriguing to a broad audience. As a result, I recommend for this paper to be accepted as a spotlight.
column2: This paper proposes a method to learn a probability distribution using a variety of approaches. The reviewers agreed that the paper is well-written, well-motivated and the approach is interesting. The main concern was about the novelty of the approach, and the novelty is not very high. The authors addressed these concerns in detail and addressed the reviewers' concerns in the rebuttal. The AC agrees with the reviewers and recommends acceptance.

column1: The paper modifies DPMs by replacing the denoising L2 losses with GANs to learn the iterative denoising process. This leads to excellent results using a small number of refinement steps. In some sense, this also takes away one of the key advantages of DPMs over GANs, which is DPMs minimize a well-defined objective function. Nevertheless, the results are convincing, but not spectacular. I am not convinced that we should continue to report training FID on CIFAR-10. I would have like to see class-conditional ImageNet results. Also, it is not clear whether the proposed technique provides additional gains on top
column2: This paper proposes a new method to improve the generalization of gradient descent models by using conditional GANs. The proposed method is a novel extension of adversarial and likelihood-based training. The reviewers agreed that the paper is well-written, well-motivated, and the experimental results are strong. The authors did a good job in addressing the concerns raised by the reviewers in the reviews. The main concerns raised were that the approach is not very simple, and that the method is not well motivated.

column1: The authors presents an alternative view of Neural ODEs, offering a novel understanding of depth in neural networks. The reviewers were overall impressed by the novelty and potential for insights this work brings. There was some disappointment that the empirical results were not stronger (both in terms of pure performance and computational cost) and that it wasn't clear how the theoretical insights into depth actually translated into a practical insight. Nevertheless, I agree with the reviewers that this is a good submission and would I think make for an interesting addition to the conference programme.
column2: This paper studies a very important and interesting topic, continuous depth neural networks. The reviewers agree that the paper is well-motivated and well-written. There are some concerns about the paper, which were addressed by the authors in the rebuttal. The authors provided a thorough analysis of the proposed model, and provided a comprehensive analysis of experimental results. Overall, the reviewers found the paper to be above the acceptance threshold for acceptance. I recommend acceptance.

column1: The paper analyzes the learning behavior of deep networks inside RL algorithms, and proposes an interesting hypothesis: that many of the observed difficulties in deep RL methods stem from _capacity loss_ of the trained network (that is, the network loses the ability to adapt quickly to fit new functions). As the paper points out, some of these difficulties have popularly been attributed to other causes (such as difficulties in exploration) or to less-specific causes (such as reward sparsity: the paper proposes that capacity loss mediates observed problems due to sparsity). The paper investigates its hypothesis two ways: first by attempting to measure how capacity varies over time during training of existing deep RL methods, and second
column2: This paper proposes a new method for learning to learn to improve the performance of deep reinforcement learning. The reviewers agree that the paper is well-written, well-motivated, and the experiments are thorough. The authors have provided a thorough rebuttal to the reviewers' concerns about the novelty of the work. The AC agrees with the reviewers that the work is interesting, well motivated, and well motivated. The main concerns raised by the reviewers are that the authors have addressed some of the concerns raised in the reviews, and that the reviewers have addressed most of them.

column1: The paper aims to solve the source-free domain adaptation, specifically on measurement shift. The proposed method lowers the domain gap via restoring the source feature distribution with a lightweight approximation. The effectiveness and performance are well validated by extensive experiments on various datasets compared with other recent methods, and the ablation analysis supports the claim of the paper well. The paper is well written with clear logic to follow.
column2: This paper proposes a method to learn a class-wise representation of a domain by training the model on a set of data. The proposed method is well-written and well-motivated, and the proposed approach is simple and effective. The paper is well written and the experimental results show that the proposed method performs well on several datasets. The reviewers were generally positive about the paper, with the main concern about the novelty and novelty of the approach. The authors did a good job in addressing the question of how to learn the class-based representation of an image. There were some concerns about the simplicity of the method, but the authors addressed these in the rebuttal phase.

column1: This paper presents a novel framing of what's at stake when selecting/segmenting text for use in language model pretraining. Four reviewers with experience working with these models agreed that the conceptual and theoretical work here is insightful and worth sharing. The empirical work is fairly small-scale and does not yet support broad conclusions, but reviewers did not see such conclusions as necessary for the paper to be valuable.
column2: This paper presents an interesting contribution to the field of neural architecture learning. The reviewers agree that the paper is well-written and well-motivated, and the results are interesting and novel. The authors have also provided a theoretical analysis of the in-context bias of the self-attention model, which is interesting. There are some concerns about the novelty of the paper, and that the experiments are limited.

column1: This manuscript expands the range of recent work in reinforcement learning for language games to much larger and more realistic datasets. A timely and relevant contribution and one that is well evaluated. Further work in stabilizing RL approaches for such large-scale problems is likely to have other far-reaching consequences. Reviewers were unanimous that this is a strong submission after the author discussion period.
column2: This paper proposes a new method to learn how to learn to learn a new language by learning a few tasks. The reviewers agreed that the paper is well-written, well-motivated, and the experiments are novel to their knowledge. The authors have provided a thorough and thorough discussion of the reviewers' concerns about the paper. The main concerns raised by the reviewers have been adequately addressed by the authors in the rebuttal phase.

column1: This work presents an approach to learning good representations for few-shot learning when supervision is provided at the super-class level and is otherwise missing at the sub-class level. After some discussion with the authors, all reviewers are supportive of this work being accepted. Two reviewers were even supportive of this work being presented at least as a spotlight. The approach presented is well motivated, experiments demonstrate its value and include a nice application in the medical domain, making the work stand out relatively to most work in few-shot classification. Therefore, I'm happy to recommend this work be accepted and receive a spotlight presentation.
column2: This paper proposes a new method to learn superclass-supervised subclasses. The reviewers agreed that the paper is well-motivated, well-written and well motivated, and the empirical results are strong. The authors did a good job in addressing the important problem of few-shot multi-graph representation learning. The main concern is that the authors did not provide a theoretical analysis of the performance of the proposed method, and that the experimental evaluation of the approach is not clear. The paper is very well written and the authors have provided a thorough rebuttal and clarifications to the reviewers' comments.

column1: The paper considers the setting of bi-level optimization and proposes a quasi-Newton scheme to reduce the cost of Jacobian inversion, which is the main bottleneck of bi-level optimization methods. The paper proves that the proposed scheme correctly estimates the true implicit gradient. The theoretical results are supported by numerical experiments, which are encouraging and show that the proposed method is either competitive with or outperforms the Jacobian Free method recently proposed in the literature. Even though the reviews expressed some initial concerns regarding the empirical performance of the proposed method, the authors adequately addressed those concerns and provided additional experiments. Thus, a consensus was reached that the paper should be accepted.
column2: This paper proposes a method to improve the performance of deep reinforcement learning. The reviewers agree that the paper is well-written and well-motivated. There were some concerns about the novelty of the proposed method, and the comparison with other methods. The authors did a good job in addressing the concerns raised by the reviewers. I recommend acceptance.

column1: The authors’ present a precise definition of deployment efficient RL, where each new update of the policy may be costly, and theoretically analyze this for finite-horizon linear MDPs. The authors include an information-theoretic lower bound for the number of deployments required. The reviewers found this an important setting of interest and appreciated the theoretical contributions. The authors’ carefully addressed the raised points and also addressed questions about deployment complexity and sample complexity in their revised work. One weakness of the paper is that it does not provide empirical results and the linear MDP assumption, while quite popular in theoretical RL over the last few years, is quite restrictive. However,the paper still provides a
column2: This paper studies RL as well motivated and timely. The authors provide a novel lower bound on the complexity of RL based on the linear MDP setting and show that it is achievable. The reviewers found that the paper is well-motivated and well-written, and the results are interesting and clear. Overall, the reviewers agreed that the work is of interest to the RL community. There were some concerns about the novelty of the paper, and that the theoretical results have not been demonstrated in practice.

column1: This paper provides generalization bounds for meta-learning based on a notion of task-relatedness. The result is natural and interesting--intuitively, when tasks are similar, then meta-learning algorithms should be able to utilize all data points across all tasks. The theoretical contribution is novel, and the results also provide more practical insight into the performances of some models.
column2: This paper proposes a new method to learn a task with a large number of classes. The paper is well-written and well-motivated, and the results are interesting and novel. The reviewers agree that the paper is an interesting contribution to the ICLR community. The main concerns raised by the reviewers are about the novelty of the paper and the simplicity of the results.

column1: This paper proposes a theoretically sound and practically effective method to compress quantized gradients and reduce communication in distributed optimization. The method is interesting and worth publication.
column2: This paper presents a new algorithm for distributed machine learning, which is based on Qwaits. The authors show that their method performs better than other methods. The main contribution of the paper is the theoretical analysis of the convergence policy. The reviewers agree that the proposed method is an interesting and novel idea.

column1: This paper revisits the information bottleneck principle, but in terms of the compression inherent in the weights of a neural network, rather than the representation. This gives the resulting IB principle a PAC-Bayes flavor. The key contribution is a generalization bound based on optimizing the objective dictated by this principle, which is then tractably approximated and experimentally verified. Reviews raise concerns about assumptions made to achieve the tractable version and a public discussion debates whether this is truly a PAC-Bayes bound. The authors address these adequately. Another concern is whether improvements in experiments can be ascribed to the new objective. Authors add new experiments in support of this. Additional concerns about the clarity of certain
column2: This paper proposes an interesting and important problem. The reviewers agree that the paper is well-written and the experiments are thorough. The main concerns raised by the reviewers have been addressed by the authors in the rebuttal. The authors are encouraged to incorporate the reviewers' comments in the final version of the paper. The AC agrees that this paper is interesting and the authors have addressed some of the concerns of the reviewers in the

column1: This manuscript proposes and analyses a bucketing method for Byzantine-robustness in non-iid federated learning. The manuscript shows how existing Byzantine-robust methods suffer vulnerabilities when the devices are non-iid, and describe a simple coordinated attack that defeats many existing defenses. In response, the primary algorithmic contribution is a bucketing approach that aggregates subgroups of devices before robust aggregation. This approach is also easily composed with existing Byzantine-robust methods. The manuscript includes an analysis of the performance of the proposed approach, including an information-theoretic lower bound for certain settings. During the review, the main concerns are related to the clarity of the technical contributions,
column2: This paper proposes a method for learning over non-iid data that is efficient and robust to adversarial attacks. The proposed method is based on a method that has been used in other work in the ML community. The authors propose to use a method called backdoor attacks to improve the performance of the approach. The paper is well-motivated and well-written, and the results are impressive. The reviewers agree that the paper is interesting, and that the approach is interesting and novel. The main concerns raised by the reviewers are about the novelty of the method and the simplicity of the experiments.

column1: The paper conducted a thorough experimental analysis of the attention map in the Conformer models for CTC based speech recognition models and connected it with phonetic and linguistic information in the speech. Using these insights, the paper presented some computation improvement and marginal quality gains. The authors actively conducted additional experiments to further justify the claims. The paper is strong in terms of the systematic way of in-depth analysis and further development (i. e. sharing the attention map across layers for speedup). But as pointed out by the reviewers, it lacks some comparisons with other alternatives to justify the importance of sharing attention maps in reducing computations. Also it would be better if there's justifications on how the observations
column2: This paper proposes a method to learn how to improve the performance of self-supervised learning. The authors show that the authors are able to reduce the inference computation by a factor of 1.100 for a 6-clock time series. The paper is well-written and well-motivated, and the reviewers agree that the proposed approach is interesting. The reviewers are not convinced about the effectiveness of the proposed method, but the authors have addressed some of the concerns raised by the reviewers in the rebuttal.

column1: The paper focused on deep regression problems and proposed a label encoding technique which can be thought as a sibling of the famous error-correcting output codes but designed for regression problems. The main idea is well illustrated in Figure 1 at the top of page 3, where the encoder and decoder are the main objects of the proposal (and a quantizer is also needed for using the encoder/decoder which is a uniform quantizer in the paper). The idea/proposal is supported by solid theoretical arguments and convincing empirical evidences (not only the paper but also the rebuttal). While there were some concerns in the beginning, the authors have successfully clarified all the concerns and then the
column2: This paper studies the problem of how to estimate the probability of the error of a classifier, and shows that the authors propose a method that performs better than other methods. The paper is well-written, well-motivated and well-done, and the authors provide a thorough analysis of the problem. The reviewers are generally positive about the paper, with some concerns about the novelty and novelty of the proposed method. The authors are not all in agreement with the reviewers, and I recommend to revise the paper to address these concerns. In particular, the authors have made a number of improvements to the presentation of the paper. The main concerns raised by the reviewers are that the paper is not

column1: The paper proposes a rotationally equivariant transformer architecture for predicting molecular properties. The proposed architecture demonstrates good computational efficiency and good results on three benchmarks. All four reviewers recommend acceptance (two weak, two strong), citing the novelty of the architecture, the good computational efficiency of the model and the good empirical results as the main strengths of the paper. The reviewers expressed minor criticisms and recommendations for improvement, some of which were addressed by the authors during the reviewing process, which led to an increase in scores. Overall, this is a nice contribution of machine learning to science, and I'm happy to recommend acceptance to ICLR.
column2: This paper proposes a method to use a transformer model to learn the dynamics of a molecular graph. The proposed method is well-motivated by the understanding of the problem and the approach is novel. The paper is well written, well-written and the experimental results are impressive. The authors are encouraged to address the concerns raised by the reviewers in the reviews.

column1: Overall, the paper provides interesting counter examples for the SGD with constant step-size (that relies on a relative noise model that diminishes at the critical points), which provide critical (counter) insights into what we consider as good convergence metrics, such as expected norm of the gradient. The initial submission took a controversial position between the mathematical statements and the presentation of the statements on the behavior of the SGD method in non-convex optimization problems. While the mathematical is sufficient for acceptance at ICLR, the presentation was inferring conclusions that could have been misread by the community. I am really happy to state that the review as well as the rebuttal processes helped improved the
column2: This paper proposes a method for training neural networks. The reviewers agreed that the paper is an interesting and interesting contribution to the field of neural network training. There were some concerns about the novelty of the paper, and the clarity of the results. The authors did a good job in addressing the concerns raised by the reviewers, and addressed most of them in the rebuttal. The main concern was that the authors did not provide a thorough comparison with the results of previous work. The paper is well-written and well-motivated, and I recommend acceptance.

column1: The paper contributes to the literature on federated learning by introducing a hybrid local SGD (HL-SGD) method. HL-SGD is motivated by the setups where edge devices are grouped into clusters with fast connections within the cluster, but slower connection between the devices and the server. HL-SGD uses hybrid updates: decentralized updates within the clusters and federated averaging steps between the clusters and the server. Initially, the reviews expressed concerns regarding comparison to prior work, empirical results, and privacy of the proposed scheme. However, the authors adequately addressed all of the concerns, added relevant discussions and results to the paper, and a consensus was reached that the paper should be accepted.
column2: The paper proposes to use a hybrid model aggregation to perform federated learning. The proposed algorithm uses a multi-task learning method to improve performance. The reviewers agreed that the paper is well-motivated and well-written. There were some concerns about the novelty of the proposed method, and the number of datasets. The authors did a good job in addressing these concerns.

column1: the paper proposed a novel idea of requiring users to complete a proof-of-work before they can read the model's prediction to prevent model extraction attacks. Reviewers were excited about the paper and ideas. Some misunderstanding raised by reviewers were sufficiently clarified by the authors in the rebuttal.
column2: This paper proposes a novel, novel, and interesting approach to the problem of adversarial attack in the context of deep learning. The paper is well-written, well-motivated, and the empirical results show that the proposed approach is a solid contribution to the field. The reviewers are generally positive about the paper, and all reviewers agree that the paper is interesting. The main concerns raised by the reviewers are about the novelty of the approach and the significance of the experimental results. The authors are encouraged to address these concerns in the rebuttal phase.

column1: This paper introduces a graph neural network (GNN) based on the finite element method (FEM) for learning partial differential equations from data. The proposed finite element network is based on a piecewise linear function approximation and a message passing GNN for dynamics' prediction. The authors also propose a method to incorporate inductive bias when learning the dynamical model, e. g. including a convection component. The paper received three clear accept and one weak accept recommendations. The reviewers discussed the possible extensions of the method, and also raise several concerns regarding experiments, e. g. the added value of a synthetic dataset, implementation tricks or hyper-parameter settings. The rebuttal did a
column2: This paper proposes a new graph neural net (GNN) method to learn the dynamics of a spatio-temporal PDE-driven dynamic model from data. The paper is well-motivated, and for the most part the description is clear. The reviewers are in agreement that the proposed method is novel and provides new ideas, and the performance is on hand with existing methods. The authors have addressed the concerns raised by the reviewers.

column1: This paper introduced a probabilistic extension to a pipeline for 3D scene geometry reconstruction from large-scale point clouds. All reviewers recognized the significance of the proposed approach and praised the simplicity of deriving a probabilistic version of Generative Cellular Automata that performs well in a number of reconstruction benchmarks. Authors were responsive during rebuttal and managed to clarify the concerns raised about the limited scope of the experiments and certain parameters involved, and also raise one reviewer's scores.
column2: This paper proposes a simple, simple and simple approach to address the problem of point cloud representation in vision. The paper proposes to use a new method to address this problem by using sparse vxel embeddings and a distance flow method. The authors show that the proposed method performs better than previous methods on large datasets. The reviewers agreed that the paper is well written and well-motivated, and the reviewers found some concerns about the novelty and novelty of the proposed approach.

column1: This paper received 4 quality reviews. The rebuttal and discussions were effective. All reviewers raised their ratings after the rebuttal. It finally received 3 ratings of 8, and 1 rating of 5. The AC concurs with the contributions made by this work and recommend acceptance.
column2: This paper proposes a novel framework to train a face detection network for the federated learning setting. The reviewers agree that the proposed method is interesting, well-motivated and well-written. The authors are in agreement that the approach can be used to improve the performance of face detection on large-scale datasets. There were some concerns about the novelty of the approach, and that the experiments are not thorough and the experimental evaluation is not thorough. The main concern was that the authors did not compare the proposed approach with existing methods, and the reviewers found that the experimental validation is somewhat weak.

column1: This paper experiments with what is required for a deep neural network to be similar to the visual activity in the ventral stream (as judged by the brainscore benchmark). The authors have several interesting contributions, such as showing that a small number of supervised updates are required to predict most of the variance in the brain activity, or that models with randomized synaptic weights can also predict a significant portion of the variance. These different points serve to better connect deep learning to important questions in neuroscience and the presence of the paper at ICLR would create good questions. The discussion between authors and reviewers resulted in a unanimous vote for acceptance, and the authors already made clarifications to the paper. I recommend acceptance.
column2: This paper presents a novel approach to an important problem, and provides a thorough study of the problem. The authors show that well-scuffed random weights can predict neural representations with significantly outperforming performance on several tasks. The reviewers agree that the paper is of interest to the ML community, and recommend acceptance. Overall, the reviewers find the paper well-written, well-motivated, and well-done.

column1: The paper proposes a new pseudometric, DARD, for comparing reward functions that avoid policy optimization. DARD builds on a recent work by Gleave et al. 2020 where the pseudometric EPIC was proposed. In contrast to EPIC, DARD operates on an approximate transition model and evaluates reward functions only on transitions close to their training distribution. Empirical experiments in different domains demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed pseudometric. The reviewers acknowledged the importance of the studied problem setting and generally appreciated the results. I want to thank the authors for their detailed responses that helped in answering some of the reviewers' questions and increased their overall assessment of the paper. At the end of the discussion phase
column2: This paper proposes a method to estimate the performance of a policy based on the distribution of the input data. The reviewers agreed that the paper is well-written and the experiments are well-done. The authors also found that the proposed method is a bit incremental to existing methods, and the empirical results are good. The main concerns raised by the reviewers were that the authors did not provide a comprehensive analysis of the number of data datasets, and that the experimental results are not comprehensive.

column1: This paper advances the long running thread of sequence modelling research focussed on differentiable instantiations of stack based models. In particular it builds upon recent work on the Nondeterministic Stack RNN (NS-RNN) by introducing three extensions. The first is to relax the need for a normalised distribution over the state and action distribution and allow unnormalised weights, this mostly serves to facilitate gradient flow and thus easier training. The second extension allows the RNN to condition on the top stack state as well as the symbol, improving expressiveness. The third improvement introduces a method for limiting the memory required to run the proposed model on long sequences, thus allowing its application to practical language
column2: This paper proposes a new method for training a neural network based on a multi-task model. The proposed changes are simple, clear, and appear to improve the model on several tasks. The paper is well-written, well-motivated, and the reviewers agree that the approach is interesting and novel. The authors have addressed the concerns raised by the reviewers by adding additional experiments and baselines. The reviewers are recommending this paper for acceptance.

column1: The paper proposes to extend mirror descent to sampling with stein operator when the density is defined on a constrained domain and non euclidean geometry. All reviewers agreed on the novelty and the merits of the paper. Accept
column2: This paper proposes a method to estimate the density of a finite number of permutations of the permutation function of a Gaussian distribution. The paper is well-written and the reviewers agree that the paper is interesting and well-motivated. The reviewers were generally positive about the paper, with the remaining concerns raised by the reviewers that the writing is not clear and the experiments are not clear. The authors have provided a thorough rebuttal to the reviewers' concerns, and the authors did a good job in the rebuttal.

column1: The paper extends MuZero to stochastic (but observable) MDPs. To represent stochastic dynamics, it splits transitions into two parts: a deterministic transition to an afterstate (incorporating all observations and actions up to the current time), followed by a stochastic outcome (accounting for new randomness that follows the last action). The transition to an afterstate is similar in spirit to ordinary MuZero's dynamics model; the stochastic outcome is learned by a VQ-VAE. At planning time, MuZero retains the MCTS lookahead from ordinary MuZero. Stochastic MuZero achieves impressive results: e. g., it
column2: This paper studies the problem of learning to learn to be more reliable by training an adversarial model with a non-trivial stochastic algorithm. The authors propose a method for learning to improve the performance of a learned non-deterministic model on the zero-player game of Game VQ-VAE. The reviewers agree that the paper is well-motivated, well-written and well-done. The main concerns raised by the reviewers have been addressed by the authors in the rebuttal.

column1: The paper addresses the problem of inconsistent gradients in multi-task learning, proposing ways to handle both their magnitude nd direction. Gradient directions are aligned by introducing a rotation layer between the shared backbone and task-specific branches. Reviewers appreciated the technical approach, higlighting the novelty of the rotation layers in this context. The empirical evaluations are systematic fair and insightful, and the presentation is polished. Reviewers unanimously supported accepting the paper.
column2: This paper proposes a method to learnable permutation-based optimizers for multi-task learning. The paper is well-written and well-motivated, and the experimental results are impressive. The proposed method is an interesting and novel contribution to the field of non-stationary neural network training. The reviewers are in agreement that the paper is a solid contribution. The authors are encouraged to address the concerns raised by the reviewers.

column1: In this paper, the authors enhance the adversarial transferability of vision transformers by introducing two novel strategies specific to the architecture of ViT models: Self-Ensemble and Token Refinement method. Comprehensive experiments on various models (including CNN's and ViT's variants) and tasks (classification, detection, and segmentation) successfully verify the effectiveness of the proposed method. In general, the problem studied is relevant and important. The paper is well-written and well-motivated with empirical findings. The proposed two strategies are novel, simple to implement, and effective in practice. Following the author's response and discussion, the average score increases from 6 to 7.5, with
column2: This paper proposes a new approach to improve the transferability of vision transformers (VIT) to adversarial attacks. The authors introduce two new methods, i. e. E. g., Semposet, and Ensembles, to improve their robustness and robustness. The reviewers agreed that the paper is well-written, well-motivated, and the reviewers found that the reviewers had some concerns about the novelty of the work. The main concerns raised by the reviewers were about the simplicity of the approach and the complexity of the proposed methods. The AC recommends acceptance.

column1: The paper demonstrates that test error of image classification models can be accurately estimated using samples generated by a GAN. Surprisingly, this relatively simple proposed method outperforms existing approaches including ones from recent competitions. All reviewers agree this is a very interesting finding, even though theoretical analysis is lacking. Given the importance of the problem of predicting generalization, I recommend acceptance.
column2: The paper is well-written, the results are important and compelling, and the related work is addressed well. The authors claim to generalize the notion of FID by applying it at multiple layers. The reviewers found the authors response to a question about theoretical justification interesting and motivated them to improve their score. The main concern raised by the reviewers is that the authors have not provided a theoretical analysis of the proposed method.

column1: All three reviewers recommend acceptance. The paper introduces an interesting study and insights on the connection between local attention and dynamic depth-wise convolution, in terms of sparse connectivity, weight sharing, and dynamic weight. The reviews included questions such as the novelty over [Cordonnier et al 2020] and the connection to Multi-scale vision longformer, which were adequately addressed by the authors. The findings in this paper should be interesting to the ICLR community.
column2: This paper studies the impact of attention-based models on image detection and classification in vision tasks. The authors show that the authors' approach is outperforming the other approaches. The paper is well-written, well-motivated and well-done. The reviewers agree that the paper is interesting and the reviewers are in agreement with the reviewers. The main concerns raised by reviewers are that the experiments are not thorough and the experiments were not thorough enough.

column1: All the reviewers think that the work is significant and new. Therefore, they support the paper to be published at ICLR 2022. Given the strong results and the “accept” consensus from the reviewers, I accept the paper as “spotlight”. The authors should implement all the reviewers’ suggestions into the final version.
column2: The paper is well written, and the main technical results are well presented. The reviewers agreed that the paper was well-motivated and well-written. The main concerns raised by the reviewers have been addressed in the revised version of the paper. The authors did a good job in addressing reviewers' concerns about the novelty of the work.

column1: This paper tackles the problem of exploration using intrinsic rewards in RL in states that have never been encountered before. The authors derive an information gain auxiliary objective that involves training an ensemble of discriminators and rewarding the policy for their disagreement, which estimates the epistemic uncertainty that comes from the discriminator not having seen enough training examples. The intrinsic reward resulting from the so-called DISDAIN (discriminator disagreement intrinsic reward) exploration bonus is more tailored to the true objective compared to pseudocount-based methods. Reviewers agree that the paper is well-motivated and well-written, that the proposed DISDAIN exploration method is simple and practical, and that experiments are convincing. Exper
column2: This paper studies the problem of how to improve the performance of an agent in the RL RL setting. The authors propose a method to improve performance of the RL environment by using an agent that is only able to solve a task with a reward function in order to be able to tackle a task. The reviewers agreed that the paper is well-written and the authors addressed the concerns raised by the reviewers, and I recommend acceptance. The paper provides a thorough analysis of the policy and empirical results in the 3-player and 4-player environments, and shows that the proposed method is effective in this setting.

column1: This paper presents an extension of the Predictive State Representation (PSRs) to multi-agent systems, with a dynamic interaction graph represents each agent’s predictive state based on its “neighborhood” agents. Three types of agent networks are considered: static complete graphs (all agents affect all others experience); static non-complete graphs (only some agents affect one another); and dynamic non-complete graphs (agents affect one another in a time varying way). A number of theoretical results are presented, including PAC bounds for the approximations in the framework. The paper also contains a number of experiments that clearly show the advantages of the proposed technique over some related methods
column2: This paper proposes a novel and simple method to learn a multi-agent model using a graph-based method. The proposed method is based on a graph based method that uses a multi agent model. The paper is of a very high quality as far as the reviewers are able to perform a thorough study of the paper. The reviewers agree that the paper is well-written and well-motivated. The authors are encouraged to make the paper more accessible to the community.

column1: Thanks for your submission to ICLR. Three of the four reviewers are ultimately (particularly after discussion) very enthusiastic about the paper, and feel that their concerns have been adequately addressed. The fourth reviewer has not updated his/her score but has indicated that their concerns were at least somewhat addressed. I took a look at their review and agree that the authors have addressed these concerns sufficiently. I am happy to recommend this paper for acceptance at this point. Note that I really appreciate the time and effort that the authors went into adding additional results and clarifications for the reviewers.
column2: This paper proposes a method to learn how to estimate the distance between the support of the optimal discriminator and the input distribution. The paper is well-written, well-motivated, and the approach is simple to understand. The reviewers agree that the paper is a solid contribution to the field. The main concerns raised by the reviewers have been addressed by the authors in the revised version of the paper.

column1: The paper presents a novel method of fusion of information from two modalities: text (context and question) and a Knowledge Base, for the task of question answering. The proposed method looks quite simple and clear, while the results show strong gains against baseline methods on 3 different datasets. Ablation studies show that the model achieves good performance on more complex questions. While the reviewers raise some concerns, e. g., on the sensitivity of the proposed method, the technical novelty against prior works, they see values in this paper in general. And the authors did a good job in their rebuttal. After several rounds of interactions, some reviewers were convinced to raise their scores by a little bit. As
column2: This paper presents a novel method of combining information from text and a kernel in a novel way. The reviewers found that the paper is well-written, well-motivated and well-done. The main concerns raised by the reviewers have been addressed by the authors. The authors did a good job in answering the reviewers' concerns.

column1: This paper addresses an important issue of AutoML systems, specifically their ability to "cold start" on a new problem. Some of the reviewers initially had concerns about the experimental validation and the theoretical foundations of the method, but during the discussion phase the authors addressed concerns extremely well. The authors already included most of the feedback of reviewers, further strengthening the paper.
column2: This paper proposes a method for learning meta-features of the target data using optimal transport. The proposed method is based on the interesting idea of learning the features of the source data as sub-features. The reviewers agree that the paper is well-written and well-motivated, and the experimental results show that the proposed method improves the performance of the proposed model. The main concerns raised by the reviewers include the novelty of the problem and the lack of clarity in the experiments. The authors are encouraged to incorporate the reviewers' comments in the final version of the paper.

column1: This paper studies the problem of motion prediction for multiple agents in a scene using transformer-based VAE like architecture. The paper received mixed reviews initially which generally tended towards borderline acceptance. All reviews appreciated extensive experiments but had some clarifications and requests for ablations. The authors provided a strong rebuttal that addressed many of the reviewers' concerns. The paper was discussed and all the reviewers updated their reviews in the post-rebuttal phase. Reviewers unanimously agree that the paper should be accepted. AC agrees with the reviewers and suggests strong acceptance. The authors are urged to incorporate reviewers' comments in the camera-ready.
column2: This paper proposes a method for generating scene-constrained predictions on a variety of datasets. The proposed method uses a transformer to learn the dynamics of the scene in order to encode and encode time and temporal information in the encoder and decoder. The reviewers agreed that the paper is well-motivated, well-written and well-done. The main concern raised by reviewers is that the novelty of the proposed method is limited, and the authors did not address these concerns in the rebuttal. The authors have addressed most of the concerns raised by the reviewers, and all reviewers agree that this is an interesting contribution to the field.

column1: All reviewers agreed that this is a strong paper, that the methodological contributions are both relevant and significant, and that the experimental validation is convincing. I fully share this viewpoint!
column2: This paper proposes a new learning method based on the proposed theory. The paper is well-written and well written. The experimental evaluation is relatively diverse (multiple datasets and benchmarks). The theoretical analysis is based on a very strong and restrictive assumption. The authors are encouraged to address the concerns raised by the reviewers in the reviews.

column1: This paper examined physics-inspired inductive biases in neural networks, in particular Hamiltonian and Lagrangian dynamics. The work separated the benefits arising from incorporating energy conservation, the symplectic bias, the coordinate systems, and second-order dynamics. Through a set of experiments, the paper showed the most important factor for improved performance in the test domains was the second-order dynamics, and not the more common explanation of energy conservation or the other factors. The increased generality of this approach was demonstrated with better predictions on Mujoco tasks that did not conserve energy. All reviewers liked the insights provided by the paper. They agreed that the paper clearly laid out several hypotheses and systematically tested them.
column2: This paper presents an interesting and novel analysis that is well-written and well-motivated. The authors have provided a thorough analysis of the importance of the complexity of the dynamics in the neural network architecture. The reviewers are generally positive about the paper, with some concerns raised about the novelty and novelty of the work. Overall, the reviewers agree that the paper is a solid contribution to the research.

column1: This paper studies the problem of dealing with long contexts within a Transformer architecture. The key contribution is a kNN memory module that works in concert with a Transformer by integrating upper layers with additional retrieved context. The idea is simple but the execution is good. While the idea is reminiscent of other recent work on this topic, and novelty is somewhat borderline, it is practically useful. Overall, though ambivalent, my recommendation is that the paper should probably be accepted
column2: This paper proposes a novel method to connect a k-NN based memory with transformers for language modeling. The paper is well-written and the proposed approach is novel and well-motivated. The reviewers agree that the proposed method is interesting and novel, and the reviewers are in agreement that the approach is interesting. The authors are encouraged to incorporate this work in the future.

column1: One might assume that the k-means problem has already been beaten to death, but this paper shows there are still remaining questions. And rather interesting ones at that, with a novel angle of having additional help from a prediction algorithm of cluster memberships. This connects to learning-augmented algorithms research. The reviewers agreed that the problem is interesting and gives a novel angle, and the interestingness stems from novelty, and the ability to "escape" from NP-hardness. The reviewers and authors had nice discussions about details and conclusions, on how limiting is it that the authors focus on reasonably accurate predictors, for instance, and where could the predictors come from. This is
column2: This paper introduces a new method for improving the accuracy of the adversarial data set. The paper is well-written and well-motivated, and the theoretical analysis is thorough. The main concerns raised by the reviewers are about the novelty of the method and the comparison with existing methods. The authors have addressed these concerns in the rebuttal.

column1: This is a deep theoretical paper with results that I consider very interesting. I have *not* had time to check them myself, but I have background in these theoretical matters and the results seem reasonable to me - the hardness of even checking the quality of a solution is well known for partition functions (as well as hardness of any reasonable approximation), but the undecidability seems new - I assume it comes naturally and it is a very interesting result - I have seen similar decidability issues for #P: general probabilistic polynomial time Turing machines (it is unclear if a connection was sought here). Reviewers are all positive about the content, and authors have acknowledge some points
column2: This paper studies the problem of how to estimate the number of parameters of a model, and the convergence of the distribution of the data. The paper is well-written, well-motivated, and well-done, with a clear contribution from the authors. The main concern is that the paper is not clear on the significance of the problem, and that there is a lack of clarity in the presentation of the results. This is an interesting contribution to the field of ML.

column1: This paper proposes Perceiver IO, a general neural architecture that handles general purpose inputs and outputs. It operates directly in the raw input domains, and thus does away with modality specific architecture components. The paper contains extensive experiments showing the capabilities of this architecture in different domains. The paper received very positive reviews from all reviewers. Some concerns included a need for additional details such as a missing task from GLUE, FLOPs comparisons to past works, nomenclature for the versions of Perceiver IO, etc. These concerns were well addressed by the authors. Others concerns by reviewers were the lack of experiments in a multi task setting. However, it was acknowledged by the authors and reviewers that
column2: This paper studies the problem of learning to learn to learn by learning from the input data. The authors propose a new neural architecture for learning to understand a variety of tasks. The proposed architecture is evaluated on several tasks, including language learning, image classification, and video image translation. The reviewers found that the proposed approach is novel and well-motivated. The main contribution of the proposed method is that it uses a latent process to encode a large number of input tokens into a hidden space, and then encode the output from this space. The paper also shows that the model can perform well with small number of inputs and large size of the output.

column1: The paper proposes an interesting hypothesis about deep nets' generalization behavior inside RL methods: it suggests that the nets' implicit regularization favors a particular form of degeneracy, in which there is excessive aliasing of state-action pairs that tend to co-occur. It proposes a new regularizer to mitigate this problem. It evaluates the hypothesis and the regularizer empirically, and it provides suggestive derivations to motivate both. The reviewers praised the comprehensive empirical analysis, the insights into learning, and the combination of empirical and theoretical evidence. The authors participated responsively and helpfully in the discussion period, and addressed any concerns raised by the reviewers. This is a strong paper: it derives
column2: This paper proposes a method to learn the Q-network with the DR3 regularizer. The reviewers found that the empirical evaluation of the proposed method is not convincing. The paper is well-written and the method proposed is simple, and the results are impressive. The authors are encouraged to address the concerns raised by the reviewers in the rebuttal phase.

column1: This work concerns Automatic Music Transcription (AMT) -- transcribing notes given the audio of the music. The paper demonstrates that a single general-purpose transformer model can perform AMT for many instruments across several different transcription datasets. The method represents the first unified AMT model that can transcribe music audio with an arbitrary number of instruments. All reviewers rated this paper highly and are excited about seeing it at the conference. One reviewer noted that "This paper seems to be a great milestone in the AMT research. It is probably the first unified AMT model that can take music audio with an arbitrary number of instruments." The reviewers had some suggestions and comments, which appear to be addressed by
column2: This paper proposes a new method for self-supervised unsupervised video and video translation of a variety of a number of different datasets. The authors provide a comprehensive analysis of the proposed method, showing that it outperforms the existing methods. The paper is well-written, well-motivated, and well-done. The reviewers are in agreement that the approach is interesting, and the authors have addressed some of the concerns raised by the reviewers. There are some concerns about the novelty of the method, but the reviewers have addressed most of them.

column1: The paper addresses a problem encountered in many real-world applications, i. e. the treatment of tabular data, composed of heterogeneous feature types, where samples are not i. i. d. In this case, learning is more effective if the typically successful approach for i. i. d. data (boosted decision trees + committee techniques) is combined with GNN to take into account the dependencies between samples. The main contribution of the paper with respect to previous work in the field is the introduction of a principled approach to pursue such integration. One important component of the proposed approach is played by the definition of a specific bi-level loss (efficient bilevel boosted smoothing
column2: This paper studies a new method for learning a graph-based classifier based on a neural network. The reviewers agree that the paper is well-written and well-motivated. The main concerns raised by the reviewers have been addressed by the authors, and were addressed during the rebuttal phase. The authors are encouraged to incorporate the reviewers' comments in the final version of the paper. The AC agrees that this is an interesting contribution to the field.

column1: This work combines steerable MLPs with equivariant message passing layers to form Steerable E(3) Equivariant GNNs (SEGNNs). It extends previous work such as Schnet and EGNNs, by allowing equivariant tensor messages (in contrast to scalar or vector messages). The paper also provides a unifying view of related work which is a nice overview for the ML community. It is overall well written, but would benefit from further revision to improve readability in some parts (in particular section 3, cf. reviews). It shows strong empirical results on the IS2RE task of the OC20 dataset and mixed results on the Q
column2: This paper proposes a new neural network model for learning on small molecules. The paper is well-motivated and well-written. The reviewers agree that the proposed method is not very competitive. The authors are encouraged to incorporate the reviewers' feedback in the revised version of the paper. The main concerns raised by the reviewers are about the novelty of the model and the performance of the proposed model.

column1: All reviewers agree that the proposed SphereFace2 approach - training face recognition models by using multiple binary classification losses - is interesting and innovative. The reviewers agree that the paper is well written and are satisfied with the presented experimental study. The rebuttal addressed all additionally raised questions. I believe that the paper will be of interest to the audience attending ICLR and would recommend a presentation of the work as a spotlight.
column2: This paper proposes a new method to improve the performance of self-supervised learning. The paper is well-written and well-motivated, and the reviewers agree that the proposed method is interesting and novel. The reviewers were generally positive about the paper, with some concerns about the novelty of the approach and the clarity of the presentation. The authors also found that the paper was very interesting and the authors did a good job in addressing the concerns raised by the reviewers. There was a concern about the lack of clarity in the authors' response to the concerns of the reviewers, which was adequately addressed in the rebuttal.

column1: This paper integrates model ensembles with randomized smoothing to improve the certified accuracy. The methodology is motivated theoretically by showing the effect of model ensemble on reducing the variance of smooth classifiers. Moreover, it proposes an adaptive sampling algorithm to reduce the computation required for certifying with randomized smoothing. Extensive experiments were conducted on CIFAR10 and ImageNet datasets. The strengths of the paper are as follows: + In terms of significance of the topic, the problem tackled in the paper is significant and highly relevant. + The motivation of using model ensemble is clearly illustrated via a figure and well justified with theoretical analysis. + Algorithmically, the paper proposes Adaptive Sampling and K
column2: This paper proposes a method for training robust robust classifiers with a variety of models. The authors provide a theoretical analysis and experiments to demonstrate the effectiveness of the method. The paper is well written and well-written, the experiments are thorough and the experiments show that the approach can be used to improve robustness. The reviewers are generally positive about the paper, with some concerns about the novelty and novelty of the approach. Overall, the paper is above the acceptance threshold.

column1: Four reviewers have evaluated this submission with one score 6 and three scores 8. Overall, reviewers like the work and note that *a rigorous and principled approach is taken by this work*. AC agrees and advocates an accept.
column2: This paper proposes a new method for training deep learning neural networks. The paper is well-written and well-motivated, and the experiments show that the proposed approach performs better than existing methods. The reviewers are generally positive about the paper, with some concerns about the novelty of the work and the clarity of the presentation. The authors are encouraged to address the concerns raised by the reviewers in the rebuttal.

column1: The paper describes a novel learning scenario where there are many related tasks, some seen at test time, and some seen only at training time, where additionally the task labels can be hidden or present. This approach generalizes both a "relational setting" (where auxiliary task labels could be used as features) and a "meta setting" (where new tasks need to be solved in a zero-shot setting using data from related tasks only). The idea behind the method is to do MTL with a common representation and a set of task-specific heads, and build a graph where (1) tasks are nodes associated with the parameters of their task-specific "heads" and (2)
column2: This paper presents a new method for learning a graph-based graph based on a number of datasets. The proposed model is based on the graph, which is then used to learn a graph of the data and the tasks. The reviewers agreed that the paper is well-motivated, well-written and well motivated. The authors had some concerns about the novelty of the proposed model, and the writing should be more clear. Overall, the paper was above the acceptance threshold for acceptance.

column1: This paper introduces a new transformer architecture for representation learning in RL. The key ingredients of the proposed architectures are a novel combination of existing methods: (1) the use of LSTMs to reduce the need for large transformers and (2) a contrastive learning procedure that doesn't require human data augmentation. The resulting approach requires less prior knowledge and provides higher sample efficiency. The paper is convincing, with comprehensive experiments on multiple challenging and well-known benchmarks and an ablation study. The reviewers did expressed concerns that parts of the paper are a very difficult read and could use improvement, especially those relying on substantial external background. The intuition behind several components could be improved, and there are
column2: This paper proposes a new method for learning a robot-based robot. The proposed approach is a novel combination of existing methods with the advantage of requiring less prior knowledge and higher sample efficiency. The reviewers agreed that the paper is well-written and well-motivated. The main concerns raised by the reviewers were about novelty, novelty and novelty of the proposed approach. The authors did a good job in the updated version, and the work is more clear and clear to follow.

column1: This paper is a solid contribution to researchers in this field, as it provides a new idea for the basic problem of determining the direction of causality between two variables, using the functional causal model as a dynamical system and optimal transport.
column2: This paper proposes a new framework for the problem of causal discovery. The paper is well-written and clear, and the paper is easy to follow. The main concern is the novelty of the theory and the lack of understanding of the problem in practice. The authors are encouraged to address these concerns in the rebuttal. The reviewers agree that this is an interesting paper.

column1: This manuscript proposes and analyses can approach to address the centralized and personalized tasks in federated learning jointly. Existing work has tackled this issue by developing separate tasks. Instead, this manuscript proposes a shared architecture that aims to optimize centralized and personalized models. One observation motivating this work is that local models trained during federated learning effectively optimize local task performance. The resulting approach results well when label shifts primarily drive the client variability. Here, the centralized components are trained to optimize a balanced risk, while the local components are trained to optimize the standard empirical risk. Reviewers agree that the manuscript is well-written and appropriately addresses the timely issue posed. The main concerns are the clarity of the technical contributions and
column2: This paper proposes a new method to improve the performance of self-supervised learning. The paper is well-written, well-motivated and motivated by a very timely problem in the field of federated learning. This is an interesting contribution to the community. The reviewers were generally positive about the paper, with some concerns about the novelty and novelty of the approach, and the clarity of the results.

column1: This paper studies model-based RL in the setting where the model can be misspecified. In this case, MLE of model parameters is a not necessarily a good idea because the error in the model estimate compounds when the model is used for planning. The authors solve this problem by optimizing a novel objective, which takes the quality of the next state prediction into account. This paper studies an important problem and this was recognized by all reviewers. Its initial reviews were positive and improved to 8, 8, 6, and 6 after the rebuttal. The rebuttal was comprehensive and exemplary. For instance, one concern of this paper was limited empirical evaluation. The authors added 5 new benchmarks and also
column2: This paper proposes a method to improve the performance of model-based reinforcement learning. The proposed method is based on an approach that uses a value-based loss function to improve performance. The paper is well-written, well-motivated, and the experiments are thorough. The authors have addressed most of the concerns raised by the reviewers. The reviewers are encouraged to incorporate the authors' responses in the final version of the paper.

column1: The authors address a very important question pertaining to the relevance of morphological complexity in the ability of transformer based conditional language models. Through extensive (controlled) experiments using 6 languages they answer as well as raise very interesting questions about the role of morphology/segmentation/vocab size which mat spawn more work in this area. All the reviewers were positive about the paper and agreed that the paper made significant contributions which would be useful to the community. More importantly, the authors and reviewers engaged in meaningful and insightful discussions through the discussion phase. The authors did a thorough job of addressing all reviewer concerns and changing the draft of the paper accordingly. I have no hesitation in recommending that this paper should be
column2: This paper presents a very interesting and interesting contribution to the field of language modeling. The reviewers agreed that the paper is well-written, well-motivated, and well-done. The main concerns raised by the reviewers were the novelty of the reviewers' feedback, and the lack of clarity in the presentation of the results. Overall, the reviewers found the paper to be an interesting contribution.

column1: The authors introduce a method for improving reinforcement learning in sparse reward settings. In particular, they propose to take advantage of a suboptimal behavior policy as a guidance policy that is incorporated in a TRPO-like update. The reviewers agree that this is a novel and interesting idea and given the authors' rebuttal with additional experiments, clarifications and discussions, they agreed to accept the paper. However, they also point out several flaws (e. g. evaluation on a more challenging sparse-reward task such as Adroid) that I encourage the authors to address in the final version of the paper.
column2: This paper proposes a novel algorithm for improving the performance of RL methods in real-world environments. The paper is well written and the analysis of the algorithm is easy to follow, and the experimental methodologies are sound. The reviewers' concern is that the reviewers are not able to compare the proposed algorithm to other methods, and that the paper is not clear on the learning rate of the proposed policy-based policy based approach. The authors are encouraged to address these concerns in the final version of the paper.

column1: This paper explores ways in which *emergent communication* (EC) methods from representation learning can be evaluated extrinsically, by hooking them into downstream NLP tasks. Reviewers agree that the paper is thorough, and finds encouraging results. This paper is borderline, and difficult to evaluate, even after very substantial discussion (some of it private). From my reading of the reviews and pieces of the paper, I'm very sympathetic to wvqW's concern that none of the present-day applications under study seem likely to benefit from this kind of emergent communication pretraining: *Natural* language pretraining, even transferring across natural languages, is for too strong a baseline,
column2: This paper proposes a new method of comparing the ability of a pre-training model to predict performance of a model on a dataset of text and image images. The authors show that the model performs well on the image classification task, and outperforms the model on the text classification task. The reviewers agree that the paper is well written, well-written and well-motivated, and the authors have addressed the concerns raised by the reviewers. The main concern is that the reviewers are not convinced that this work can be used in a practical case, and that the results are not very convincing.

column1: The authors introduce the Time-Aware Multiperistence Spatio-Supra Graph CN that uses multiparameter persistence to capture the latent time dependencies in spatio-temporal data. This is a novel and experimentally well-supported work. The novelty is achieved by combining research in topological analysis (multipersistence) and neural networks. Technically sound. Clear presentation and extensive experimental section. Reviewers were uniformly positive, agreeing that the approach was interesting and well-motivated, and the experiments convincing. Some concerns that were raised were successfully addressed by the authors and revised in the manuscript. Happy to recommend acceptance. A veru nice paper!
column2: This paper proposes to use multi-parameter drift to learn time-dependent properties of spatio-temporal data and be a part of time-aware learning of a convolutional network. The paper presents a novel research direction with improved performance on a variety of datasets. The reviewers agreed that the paper is well-written and well-motivated, and the experimental results are thorough and thorough. The main concerns raised by the reviewers are that the approach is interesting and novel, and that the empirical results are impressive.

column1: This paper is a resource and numerical investigation into the variability of BERT checkpoints. It also provides a bootstrap method for making investigations on the checkpoints. All reviewers appreciate this contribution that can be expected to be used by the NLP community.
column2: This paper proposes a method to estimate the model uncertainty of the model. The proposed method is novel and theoretical sound, which is useful for understanding the large models. The reviewers agreed that the paper is well-written and well-motivated. The main contribution of the work is the multi-strawait framework, which seems to be the main contribution in this paper. Overall, I think it is not clear to me how the authors estimate the distribution of the error over the samples and test examples. The authors have addressed the problem of using anomalyual model models as the base for experiments in ML.

column1: This paper proposes a message passing neural network to solve PDEs. The paper has sound motivation, clear methodology, and extensive empirical study. However, on the other hand, some reviewers also raised their concerns, especially regarding the lack of clear notations and sufficient discussions on the difference between the proposed method and previous works. Furthermore, there is no ablation study and the generalization to multiple spatial resolution is not clearly explained. The authors did a very good job during the rebuttal period: many concerns/doubts/questions from the reviewers were successfully addressed and additional experiments have been performed to support the authors' answers. As a result, several reviewers decided to raise their scores,
column2: This paper proposes an approach to improve the performance of a neural network based on an adversarial learning method. The paper is well-written and well-motivated, with thorough and thorough analysis of the literature. The reviewers agree that the paper is very well written, with clear empirical results. The authors are not clear about the importance of the use of graph convolutional neural networks (GNNs) to improve performance of the method, but the authors provide a thorough discussion in the rebuttal. Overall, I recommend accept this paper.

column1: I thank the authors for their submission and active participation in the discussions. All reviewers are unanimously leaning towards acceptance of this paper. Reviewers in particular liked that the paper is well-written and easy to follow [186e,TAdH,Exgo], well motivated [TAdH], interesting [PsKh], novel [186e] and provides gains over baselines [186e,TAdH,PsKh] with interesting ablations [186e,Exgo]. I thus recommend accepting the paper and I encourage the authors to further improve their paper based on the reviewer feedback.
column2: This paper proposes a method to improve the performance of agents in two-player games. The main contribution is a strategy with an in-sample change of the policy of the agent. The paper is well-written and well-motivated, but the main method section is not clear. The authors have addressed the concerns raised by the reviewers in the reviews and the reviews are generally positive.

column1: This paper provides a very large-scale study on the pretraining of image recognition models. Specifically, three scaling factors (model sizes, dataset sizes, and training time) are extensively investigated. One important phenomenon observed by this paper is that stronger upstream accuracy may not necessarily contribute to stronger performance on downstream tasks---actually sometimes these two types of performance could even be at odds with each other Overall, all the reviewers enjoy reading this paper and highly appreciate the empirical results presented in this paper. There were only a few concerns raised by the reviewers but most were well addressed during the discussion period. All reviewers reach a consensus on accepting this paper and believe this study is worthy to be heard by the community.
column2: The paper is well-written and easy to follow, as well as well-motivated and clear-written. The reviewers agreed that the paper was well-done, and that the authors have addressed a very important problem. The authors did a good job in the rebuttal phase, and addressed the concerns raised by the reviewers. There were some concerns about the novelty of the approach, and the authors addressed these in the revised version.

column1: The paper studies an interesting question of whether neural networks can approximate the target function while keep the output in the constraint set. The constraint set is quite natural for e. g. multi-class classification, where the output has to stay on on the probability manifold.
