The challenge here is that traditional universal approximation theory only guarantees that f^(x)≈f(x), but can not guarantee that f^(x) lies exactly in the same constraint set as f(x). The paper made a significant contribution in the theory of deep learning -- It is shown that the neural network can indeed approximate any regular functions while keep the output stay in the regular constraint set. This gives
column2: This paper studies the problem of training neural networks with sub-constrained parameters. The paper shows that the neural network can be trained with permutation functions, which can be applied to a set of sub-parametries. The reviewers agreed that the paper is well-written and well-motivated. The main concerns raised by the reviewers have been addressed by the authors in the rebuttal.

column1: This is a strong empirical paper that studies scaling laws for NMT in terms of several new aspects, such as the model quality as a function of the encoder and decoder sizes, and how the composition of data affects scaling, etc. The extensive empricial results offer new insights to the questions and provide valuable guidance for future research on deep NMT. The datasets used in the study are non-public, which may make it hard to reproduce the evaluation.
column2: This paper provides experiments to explore how the complexity of training and test data can be used to estimate the distribution of the loss of the training data in a model. The reviewers agreed that the paper is well-written and well-motivated. The authors provided a thorough rebuttal on the paper and addressed the concerns raised by the reviewers. The paper also addressed the concern of the lack of experiments on the number of encoder and decoder layers, and the comparison to other baselines that are used in the paper.

column1: The authors present a method called "AdaRL" that learns a structured latent representation that characterizes relationships between different variables in an RL system. The method is evaluated on modified Pong and Cart-Pole domains and it is shown to outperform other transfer learning baselines. The reviewers agree that the method makes sense and addresses an important problem of transfer in RL. The authors did a good job in the rebuttal to empirically validate their claims and provided extra experiments. The reviewers also point out that the evaluated domains are rather simple and the paper would benefit from evaluations in a more complex environment as well as better writing. Please focus on improving these aspects in the final version of the paper
column2: This paper proposes a new method to improve the generalization of the adversarial agent learning problem. The paper is well-written and the reviewers agreed that the proposed method is interesting and novel. The reviewers had some concerns about the novelty of the method and the simplicity of the experiments. The authors did a good job in addressing reviewers' concerns about novelty and the clarity of the experimental results. Overall, the authors provided an interesting contribution to the research community.

column1: This paper introduces a novel SE(3) equivariant graph matching network, along with a keypoint discovery and alignment approach, for the problem of protein-protein docking, with a novel loss based on optimal transport. The overall consensus is that this is an impactful solution to an important problem, whereby competitive results are achieved without the need for templates, refinement, and are achieved with substantially faster run times.
column2: The paper proposes a method to learn graph representations of molecular structures. The proposed method is based on Graph Matching Networks and E(3) Equivariant Graph Neural Networks. The paper is well written and the theoreticalization of the method is very simple. The authors also provide a theoretical analysis of the proposed method. The reviewers agree that the paper is novel and the approach is interesting. The main concerns raised by the reviewers are that the method does not perform as well as existing methods, and that the authors have provided a number of experimental results that are not clear.

column1: The paper reviews and draws connections between several parameter-efficient fine-tuning methods. All reviewers found the paper addresses an important research problem, and the theoretical justification and empirical analyses are convincing.
column2: This paper proposes a new framework for gradient descent learning, which uses a variety of methods. The reviewers agreed that the paper is well-written and well-motivated. The authors also found that the proposed method is more effective than existing methods on several tasks. The main concerns raised by the reviewers were the lack of comparison with existing methods and lack of robustness of the results. Overall, the reviewers found the paper to be a solid contribution.

column1: This paper introduces a new type of language model, the GNN-LM, which uses a graph neural network to allow a language model to reference similar contexts in the training corpus in addition to the input context. The empirical results are good, and the model sets a new SOTA on the benchmark Wikitext-103 corpus, as well as improving over strong baselines on two other language modeling datasets (enwiki8 and Billion Word Benchmark). The main drawback, as noted by one reviewer, is the computational expense of the method with significant slowdowns compared to the baseline. Two reviewers voted strong accept, with a third raising several concerns. The largest concern was the lack of comparison to
column2: This paper proposes a method to learn the context of the text from the training data. The proposed model is shown to perform better than a standard language model on several benchmarks. The paper is well-motivated, well-written, and well-done. The reviewers agree that the paper is above the acceptance threshold. The main concerns raised by the reviewers have been addressed by the authors in the rebuttal.

column1: The authors propose a memory-based continual learning method that decomposes the models' parameters and that shares a large number of the decomposed parameters across tasks. In other words, only a small number of parameters are task-specific and the memory usage of storing models from previous tasks is hence a fraction of the memory usage of previous approaches. column1: This paper proposes an innovative method for continual learning that modifies the direction of gradients on a new task to minimise forgetting on previous tasks without data replay. The method is mathematically rigorous with a strong theoretical analysis and excellent empirical results across multiple continual learning benchmarks. It is a clear accept. There was good discussion between the reviewers and authors that addressed a number of minor issues, including clarifying that the method has the same computational complexity as backpropagation. The authors are encouraged to make sure that these points are addressed in the final version of the paper.
column2: This paper proposes a method to learn a task using a graph of the gradient of the output of a task, and a map of the input. The proposed approach is novel, and the reviewers agree that it is interesting and novel. The reviewers are in agreement that this is a nice idea and a nice application of it. The authors have provided a thorough rebuttal to reviewers' concerns about the paper, and provided additional experimental results. The AC agrees that the paper is a solid contribution to the community, and I recommend acceptance. There were some concerns raised by the reviewers about the novelty of the approach and the clarity of the experiments.
